video_title: From Zero to Your First AI Agent in 25 Minutes (No Coding)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
🖥️ Download the free AI Agents Resources: https://clickhubspot.com/39c59b

More from Futurepedia:
👉 Join the fastest-growing AI education platform! Try it free and explore 20+ top-rated courses in AI: https://bit.ly/futurepediaSL

Links:
n8n - https://n8n.partnerlinks.io/Futurepedia

Summary
If you're new to AI agents, this is the perfect place to start. In just 25 minutes, you'll learn exactly what an AI agent is, how it differs from traditional automations, and how to build one from scratch using n8n — no coding required. We’ll cover the core components of agent systems, how to set up guardrails, how agents interact with APIs, and what kinds of tools they can use. By the end, you'll have a working AI agent that can think, remember, and take action — and a clear understanding of how to build more. This is a hands-on, beginner-friendly guide designed to take you from zero to a working agent with practical, real-world applications.

video_title: From Zero to Your First AI Agent in 25 Minutes (No Coding)
author: @Marco916SacTown
comment: One thing I'm learning about putting together agents and non-agent automations: the true conduit, the magic, is the APIs. Those cost extra if you're trying to put something together. While many platforms advertise their AI capabilities, the real power comes from connecting different services through robust APIs. This integration allows for more complex workflows and customized solutions, but the pricing models often hide these additional costs until you're deep into development. Worth considering these expenses upfront when planning your next automation project.

video_title: From Zero to Your First AI Agent in 25 Minutes (No Coding)
author: @HowToAIFast
comment:
1 month ago

I'm not 70 yet — but I am a lifelong tinkerer raised on dusty keyboards, late-night coding marathons, and a deep love for tech that keeps evolving faster than I can blink. This video hit me like a lightning bolt .

For someone trying to bridge the gap between classic know-how and the AI revolution, this tutorial didn’t just inform — it empowered. I’ve spent the past few weeks knee-deep in agents, APIs, and automation stacks, trying to make sense of how it all connects. Your clarity, pacing, and real-world examples lit up the path like a lantern in the fog .

What stood out most? You treated the audience with respect — no overhyped “get rich quick” vibes, just thoughtful guidance that feels like a conversation, not a sales pitch. That’s rare these days.

 Now, thanks to this video, I’ve successfully built my first working AI agent, and I’m already sketching out a system to streamline tasks for a local family business in Việt Nam. You’ve not just taught — you’ve inspired.

 Subscribed. Notifications on. Waiting for your next masterpiece.

video_title: OpenAI’s Sam Altman Talks ChatGPT, AI Agents and Superintelligence — Live at TED2025
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
The AI revolution is here to stay, says Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI. In a probing, live conversation with head of TED Chris Anderson, Altman discusses the astonishing growth of AI and shows how models like ChatGPT could soon become extensions of ourselves. He also addresses questions of safety, power and moral authority, reflecting on the world he envisions — where AI will almost certainly outpace human intelligence. (Recorded live at TED2025 on April 11, 2025)

author: @ВениаминФеафанов
comment:
Just to point that out: functions only take one argument. So what the "addition" function:
λx. λy. x + y
actually does is it takes x and then returns a function:
λy. x + y
where x is replaced with given input and y is expected as another input, but that's another function. And that's what is the coolest thing about the lambda-calculus: black boxes can take black boxes and return black boxes.

This way `TRUE FALSE TRUE` look very strangle but have meaning. Using other syntax we could write this like that: `TRUE(FALSE, TRUE)` this look and work same as `f(5)` or `sin(Pi*2)` but instead returning number its return another function. As a approximation we could write `λ x. λ y. x + y` as `f(x,y) = x + y` and `λ b. FALSE TRUE` as `not(b) = b(FALSE, TRUE)`.

He says, correctly, that the lambda calculus includes functions and variables and a means of application... but he previously used an addition operator and the number '1'.  Lambda calculus does not include either of those things.  They have to be constructed.  The ways they are constructed are pretty interesting, IMO.

video_title: Essentials: Functional Programming's Y Combinator - Computerphile
author: @CheezyRusher
comment:
Because this video basically said go to wikipedia, I'll try to explain what Y Combinator is.

YC is a way to name your function in a language that does not allow such pointers. It proves that function names, classes, etc. are just syntactic sugar. Let's look at the same example:

function factorialFn(number){ 
    return number == 1 ? 1: number * factorialFn(number-1)
}

The only thing that generates a pointer in lambda calculus is a function parameter. So let's rewrite everything to anonymous functions.

// This is the mind bending part, a function takes in the factorial function, returns factorial function that takes a number
(factorialFn)=>
  (number) =>  number == 1 ? 1: number * factorialFn(number-1)

Let's call this our Prepared function - we know it would work, but we don't know how to run it yet.

So how do we pass the internal function into itself? Looks impossible, right? We could just pass garbage(empty function) to get the internal function and use this to generate the actual function. 

((factorialFn)=>
  (number) =>  number == 1 ? 1: number * factorialFn(number-1))
(((factorialFn)=>
    (number) =>  number == 1 ? 1: number * factorialFn(number-1))
(()=> console.log('garbage')))

Trying number 2 would return a correct answer, but number 3 would call the garbage function. 

You could just calculate how many times you will need to recurse and nest that many times, so that garbage function would never get called? :P Kinda defeats the purpose. What if we made a function that would nest functions for us?

Let's look at the same example as in the video of the simplest recursion:

(fn) => fn(fn)

If we give this function to itself, it will repeat to no end:

((x) => x(x))((y) => y(y)) 

same fn, just different variable names for readability. The "y" function becomes a variable "x" after the first application, the x function repeats to infinity. This is the essence of YC. So how do we make this to call our function?

Well Lambda calculus allows only way, same as before, as a function parameter:

(yourPreparedFn) => 
   (x => x(x))(y => yourPreparedFn(number => y(y)(number)))

// The number function exists because I wanted this to be valid JS, and JS is not lazy - it's arguments are immediately evaluated, else the second part could have been just y=> yourPreparedFn(y(y))

If you try to run the function in your head, you will see that the "y" variable is "y" function itself. The first part (x => x(x)) makes that happen as it calls the function and passes the function to itself. And now you are thinking with portals.

The second part becomes easier to understand. Because y function has a reference to itself, it has an ability to loop by simply doing y(y). And it can share this ability with your Prepared function. When your Prepared function calls factorialFn with the next number, it's not actually calling factorialFn - it calls y function that generates the next factorialFn and then calls it with the number you passed.

This is it, that's Y combinator:

Y = f => (x => x(x))(x => f(y => x(x)(y)))

You can run this JS to and try to debug or break it for better understanding:

((yourPreparedFn) => 
   (x => x(x))(y => yourPreparedFn(number => y(y)(number))))
((factorialFn)=>
  (number) =>  number == 1 ? 1: number * factorialFn(number-1))
(5)

Don't worry if it takes a long time to get it - took me more than a day the first time and I had better resources than a youtube comment :)

video_title: Essentials: Functional Programming's Y Combinator - Computerphile
author: @kosnk
comment:
What puzzled is that the `f(f(f(…)))` expanding never actually ends!
Which to me meant that the argument of `f` will never be calculated, thus we won't ever be able to call the `f`.

But that's only true if we eagerly evaluate the arguments. But we can postpone this evaluation until it's needed.
E.g. in the factorial calculator we only need `f` when we call it in the "else" case:

var fac_calc = f => n =>
    n == 0
    ? 1
    : n * f(n -1)      // < only here we need the actual function of the `f`

which means that the actual unwrapping of `f` to the next step of recursion in `f(…)` can happen on demand.
So `f(f(…))` turns into `f( lazy f ( lazy f(…) ) )`.

For laziness we can declare functions with no arguments, that upon call will do some calculations:

() => calculate_the_answer(42)

Thus we redefine our `rec` and `fac_calc` to use lazy evaluation:

var rec = f => f(() => rec( f ) )

Then we can define our factorial calculator as:

var fac_calc = f => n =>
    n == 0
    ? 1
    : n * f()(n -1)      // unwrap lazy `f` and then call it

And then derive factorial fn from rec + fac_calc:

var fac = rec(fac_calc);

And finally call it:

fac(3); // = 6

Hope it helps someone else.
Also see CheezyRusher's comment with great explanation of Y Combinator.

P.S.: this is how we can define lazy `rec` via a Y combinator:

var rec = f => (x => f(() => x(x))) (x => f(() => x(x)))

author: @jackkraus6948
comment:
What I first used lambda functions for was when I created minesweeper in tkinter. The button components took a function parameter to call when pressed. Since in Minesweeper pressing an empty cell (no adjacent bombs, i.e. no number) reveals the cells around it, I wrote a recursive function that when given a row and column number revealed the cell value in that spot and called the function for the cells around it if the cell was empty. I used lambda to iteratively create functions using that function while passing in a set row and column.
TL:DR you can use lambda to create a version of a defined function with filled in parameters

video_title: Lambda Calculus - Fundamentals of Lambda Calculus & Functional Programming in JavaScript
author: @codegeek98
comment:
[0:00:00] Intro
[0:00:48] I = a => a
[0:01:48] Notation
[0:06:39] Functions
[] Beta-reduction
[] M = f => f(f)
[] "n-ary" shorthand
[] K = a => b => a
[] KI = a => b => b
[] History
[] Combinators?
[] C = f => a => b => f(b)(a)
[] T = K; F = KI
[] not = p => p(F)(T)
[] not == C && not !== C
[] and = p => q => p(q)(p)
[] or = p => q => p(p)(q)
[] or == M

video_title: Curried Functions - Computerphile
author: @kevinbee4617
comment:
The fact that functions in Haskell are curried by default explains the function signatures with multiple arrows.

"add x y = x+y" has the type "Integer -> Integer -> Integer" A function that takes and Int and produces another function that takes another Int and produces an Int

"add (x y) = x + y" has the type "(Integer, Integer) -> Integer" – Like you would expect in Java "int add(int x, int y) {return x + y;}".  
By the way, that notation is a fancy way to write "add pair = (first pair) + (second pair)". It really only has  parameter "pair".

comment: Hi Mosh. I have taken your courses on codewithmosh.I have nothing but mad respect for you, brother. I've watched your channel go from under a million subscribers to over 4 million. As someone over 50 learning to program, I have enjoyed and learned from your teaching style. But I have a recommendation: Teach specific courses aimed at those, like me, who are not looking for a traditional employment, but wants to learn programming to develop programs (AI agents, data driven tools, web and native apps, interactive games, etc.), or become a consultant. We need more and more tech entrepreneurs.

author: @_somerandomguyontheinternet_
comment:
Regarding programming patterns, they’re very, very useful to learn, but you should never be itching to use a pattern. The patterns solve problems, so don’t use it unless you have the problem it was made for.
It’s as my professor used to say: “If you wake up in the morning and the first thought that pops into your mind is ‘I wonder what design pattern I can use at work today,’ it’s a great day to call your boss and say you’re very sick and you’re not going to work.”

{ Thanks for creating such a valuable video }

02:39 Download a code editor like Visual Studio Code to start learning web development.
 CSS is essential for front-end development and includes both pure CSS and frameworks
 JavaScript controls web actions.
 Learn version control system, specifically Git and GitHub.
 Transition from Vanilla JavaScript to using libraries and frameworks
 Technology and creativity are crucial for standout projects and job applications.
 Writing tests and learning TypeScript are important for front end developers.
 Front-end developers can get high package salary with no limit

video_title: AWS SageMaker 지상 진실 레이블링 작업 튜토리얼 🔥
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
머신 러닝 모델 학습을 위한 데이터 세트를 생성하기 위해 이미지에 레이블을 지정하려고 합니다.

SageMaker Ground Truth에서 레이블 지정 작업을 설정하면 이 작업을 수행할 수 있습니까?

--
SageMaker는 완전 관리형 인프라, 도구 및 워크플로를 통해 모든 사용 사례에 대한 머신 러닝(ML) 모델을 준비하고 구축, 학습 및 배포하는 완전 관리형 서비스입니다.

--
튜토리얼 요약:
AWS Sagemaker Groundtruth 레이블 지정 작업에서 작업 범주에 대한 이미지를 선택하여 시작합니다.
머신 러닝 모델용 데이터 세트를 생성하기 위한 레이블 지정 작업을 설정합니다.
S3 서비스로 이동하여 이미지(고양이와 개 이미지 6장)를 테스트 버킷에 업로드합니다.
Amazon SageMaker 서비스에서 Ground Truth로 이동하여 레이블 지정 작업을 생성합니다.
작업 이름을 지정하고, 자동 데이터 설정을 선택하고, S3 테스트 버킷을 선택합니다.
테스트 버킷에 대한 액세스 권한이 있는 새 IAM 역할을 생성하고 데이터 설정을 완료합니다.
테스트 버킷에 매니페스트 파일이 있는지 확인합니다.
작업 범주를 단일 레이블 이미지 분류로 선택합니다.
작업자 유형에서 비공개를 선택하고 작업자 이메일 주소를 입력합니다.
시간 초과 및 만료 시간은 기본값으로 둡니다.
조직 및 지원 이메일을 입력합니다.

video_title: vSphere Certificate Manager를 사용하여 VMware vCenter 인증서 만료 문제를 해결하는 방법
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Renewing vCenter Certificates Using VMware Certificate Manager - vCenter error- no healthy upstream.

In today’s video, I’ll guide you through the process of renewing vCenter certificates using VMware Certificate Manager. If you’re facing issues accessing your vCenter server or seeing errors like “No healthy upstream,” there’s a good chance your vCenter certificate has expired, causing critical services to stop.

This tutorial will walk you through each step, from identifying expired certificates to resetting them and regaining access to your vCenter environment.

🔍 What You’ll Learn:
How to identify expired vCenter certificates.
How to access the vCenter Server Appliance via SSH to check vCenter certificate expiration details.
Step-by-step guide to using the vSphere Certificate Manager to renew vCenter SSL certificates.
Replacing all certificates and reconfiguring necessary details for a smooth vCenter certificate renewal.
Verifying successful access to vCenter after completing the VMware vCenter SSL certificate renewal process.
⚙️ Course Content:
Troubleshooting vCenter access errors related to certificate expiration.
Command-line steps for verifying certificate expiration on the vCenter appliance.
How to use vSphere Certificate Manager to replace SSL certificates and resolve the vCenter certificate expired issue.
Inputting vCenter details like IP address and hostname to complete the reset.
Final verification of a successful renewal by accessing the vCenter console.
📚 Who Should Watch:
VMware admins and engineers working with vSphere and vCenter Server.
IT professionals managing VMware environments who need to troubleshoot and fix vCenter certificate expired issues.
Anyone looking for a hands-on tutorial on using the vSphere Certificate Manager for vCenter SSL certificate renewal.
🔔 Stay Updated: Don’t forget to like, share, and subscribe for more tutorials on VMware vCenter, vSphere, and cloud computing best practices.

📚 Related Playlists:
VMware vSphere Troubleshooting
VMware vCenter Management and Maintenance
VMware Certificate Manager Tutorials
💬 Connect with Us:
LinkedIn:   / globaltechnologyoptions  
Facebook:   / globaltechnologyoptions  
YouTube:    / @globaltechnologyoptions  

Got questions about vCenter certificate renewal, or how to use vSphere Certificate Manager to replace SSL certificates? Drop them in the comments, and we’ll be happy to assist!

for store in $(/usr/lib/vmware-vmafd/bin/vecs-cli store list | grep -v TRUSTED_ROOT_CRLS); do echo "[*] Store :" $store;  /usr/lib/vmware-vmafd/bin/vecs-cli entry list --store $store --text | grep -ie "Alias" -ie "Not After"; done;

video_title: How to Cultivate Production Excellence with Liz Fong-Jones, Honeycomb
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this presentation from the first ever multi-cloud conference Liz Fong-Jones from Honeycomb explains how to cultivate production excellence. 

Taming the complex distributed systems we're responsible for requires changing not just the tools and technical approaches we use; it also requires changing who is involved in production, how they collaborate, and how we measure success.

In this talk, you'll learn about several practices core to production excellence: giving everyone a stake in production, collaborating to ensure observability, measuring with Service Level Objectives, and prioritizing improvements using risk analysis.

video_title: Asymmetric (Follow-the-Sun) Workloads in CockroachDB Cloud
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
What if you could run one global database without having to worry about resourcing for each region? 

If you're planning on self-hosting a multi-region CockroachDB cluster, you will need to know how many nodes you need in each region. In our Standard Tier in CockroachDB Cloud, you can choose a specific number of vCPUs to use across the entire cluster. To get started with CockroachDB Cloud for free, visit https://cockroa.ch/3DVXbwF

For example, if one region is busier than another at any given time, it will receive more vCPUs. As usage patterns shift across the cluster and regions change throughout the day, so will the distribution of vCPUs.

To show you how Asymmetric Workloads in CockroachDB Cloud work, join Cockroach Labs Technical Evangelist Rob Reid as he brings explanations, diagrams, and demos with a financial services use case to this video.

00:00 Why asymmetric workloads?
00:42 A visual explanation
02:26 Creating a multi-region CockroachDB cluster
02:43 The global CockroachDB load balancer
03:04 Setting the default db's primary region
03:27 What do asymmetric workloads look like?
03:55 How to view data in the CockroachDB console
05:42 Why we recommend the Standard tier for most production workloads

About Cockroach Labs: 
Cockroach Labs is a pioneering software company at the forefront of database technology, dedicated to delivering resilient and scalable database solutions to run mission-critical workloads for the world's most important businesses. With a mission to scale when others fail, Cockroach Labs is revolutionizing the way businesses manage their data with its innovative cloud native distributed SQL database, CockroachDB.

About the CockroachDB Cloud platform:
The CockroachDB Cloud platform dramatically simplifies database operations so you can build and run more resilient applications. The Standard Tier in CockroachDB supports a range of production workloads with enterprise-level security.

video_title: A4Q 테스팅 서밋 취리히 - 사용 중심 테스트를 활용하여 E2E 테스트 자동화 최적화
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Bruno is Professor of Software Engineering at the University of Franche-Comté (France), and co-founder of Smartesting. He is one of the leaders of the CFTL (French Testing Board) and has co-piloted the ISTQB® task forces for the "Model-Based Testing" and "Acceptance Testing" syllabi.

He will be joining us at the A4Q Global Testing summit to address the key topic of end-to-end test coverage (E2E),which is a major difficulty for many teams, as these tests need to be representative of actual user journeys, and often detail information is missing.

Register now for a a practical overview of the Usage-centric Testing approach, its implementation and the benefits it can bring for testers and the whole team.

Find out more 👉 https://a4qworldcongress.com/

author: @HowToAIFast
comment:
1 month ago

I'm not 70 yet — but I am a lifelong tinkerer raised on dusty keyboards, late-night coding marathons, and a deep love for tech that keeps evolving faster than I can blink. This video hit me like a lightning bolt .

For someone trying to bridge the gap between classic know-how and the AI revolution, this tutorial didn’t just inform — it empowered. I’ve spent the past few weeks knee-deep in agents, APIs, and automation stacks, trying to make sense of how it all connects. Your clarity, pacing, and real-world examples lit up the path like a lantern in the fog .

What stood out most? You treated the audience with respect — no overhyped “get rich quick” vibes, just thoughtful guidance that feels like a conversation, not a sales pitch. That’s rare these days.

 Now, thanks to this video, I’ve successfully built my first working AI agent, and I’m already sketching out a system to streamline tasks for a local family business in Việt Nam. You’ve not just taught — you’ve inspired.

 Subscribed. Notifications on. Waiting for your next masterpiece.

video_title: From Zero to Your First AI Agent in 25 Minutes (No Coding)
author: @psnts-5ao
comment: The distinction you made between 'automation' (fixed rules) and 'agents' (reasoning) finally made it click for me. I’ve been building rigid Zapier flows for years wondering why they felt so dumb. I’m definitely going to try this n8n setup. I usually just output my daily logs to a static HTML dashboard on Tiiny Host or Vercel so I can check them on my phone, but having the agent actually email me with a decision based on the weather is way smarter. Great tutorial!

video_title: OpenAI’s Sam Altman Talks ChatGPT, AI Agents and Superintelligence — Live at TED2025
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
The AI revolution is here to stay, says Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI. In a probing, live conversation with head of TED Chris Anderson, Altman discusses the astonishing growth of AI and shows how models like ChatGPT could soon become extensions of ourselves. He also addresses questions of safety, power and moral authority, reflecting on the world he envisions — where AI will almost certainly outpace human intelligence. (Recorded live at TED2025 on April 11, 2025)

video_title: Microsoft Team just Released FARA-7B: An Efficient Agentic AI Model for Computer Use
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Fara-7B는 Microsoft의 7B 매개변수로, 스크린샷과 텍스트를 기반으로 사용자 장치에서 직접 실제 웹 작업을 자동화하는 개방형 가중치 컴퓨터 사용 에이전트입니다. Qwen2.5-VL-7B를 기반으로 구축되고 FaraGen 파이프라인에서 검증된 145,603개의 궤적을 학습한 이 알고리즘은 WebVoyager에서 73.5%, WebTailBench에서 38.4%의 성공률을 달성하는 동시에 비용 효율성을 유지하고 더욱 안전한 브라우저 자동화를 위한 임계점 및 거부 보호 장치를 적용합니다.

전체 분석: https://www.marktechpost.com/2025/11/...

논문: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/resea...

모델 가중치: https://huggingface.co/microsoft/Fara-7B

기술 세부 정보: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/resea...

video_title: Microsoft Team just Released FARA-7B: An Efficient Agentic AI Model for Computer Use
comment:
Fara-7B is Microsoft’s 7B parameter, open weight Computer Use Agent that runs on screenshots and text to automate real web tasks directly on user devices. Built on Qwen2.5-VL-7B and trained on 145,603 verified trajectories from the FaraGen pipeline, it achieves 73.5 percent success on WebVoyager and 38.4 percent on WebTailBench while staying cost efficient and enforcing Critical Point and refusal safeguards for safer browser automation....

최근 구글 제미나이가 대규모 업데이트를 진행했는데요.
제가 오랫동안 써왔던 챗지피티에서 제미나이로 완전히 갈아타게 만든 결정적인 기능들이 있습니다.
오늘 영상에서는 챗지피티에는 없는, 오직 제미나이만 가능한 미친 기능 세 가지를 탈탈 털어 알려드릴 겁니다.  특히 제가 실생활에서 어떻게 써먹고 있는지, 그 활용 꿀팁까지 전부 공개할 예정이니까요. 

Ai로 진짜 삶의 질을 바꾸고 싶다면, 꼭 끝까지 시청해주세요.

video_title: 코딩할 줄 몰라도 다 된다... AI가 연 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 부상, 진짜 개발자는 없어지나?
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
인공지능 코딩 보조 기술인 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 도구의 부상으로 소프트웨어 개발 방식이 근본적으로 변화하고 있습니다. 테슬라와 OpenAI에서 활동한 안드레이 카파시가 제시한 바이브 코딩은 AI에게 자연어로 지시하여 프로그램을 만드는 새로운 코딩 방식입니다. 이는 GPT-4, LLaMA 같은 초거대 언어 모델이 방대한 데이터로 학습되어 가능해졌습니다. 대표적인 AI 코딩 도구인 Cursor AI나 GitHub Copilot은 코드 생성 및 수정, 버그 해결 보조 등을 통해 개발 생산성을 크게 높이고 있습니다. AI가 코딩 작업 속도를 평균 55%까지 빠르게 하지만, 개발자는 AI가 생성한 코드를 검토하고 통합하는 데 더 많은 시간을 할애하기도 합니다. 한편, 로우코드/노코드 플랫폼은 적은 코드 또는 코드 작성 없이도 애플리케이션 제작을 가능하게 하여 개발의 민주화를 목표로 합니다. 이는 개발 인력 부족과 소프트웨어 수요 증가 문제를 해결하고, 현업과 개발자 간 소통을 원활하게 하는 대안으로 주목받고 있습니다. 가트너에 따르면 글로벌 로우코드/노코드 시장은 고속 성장 중이며, Microsoft Power Platform과 같은 플랫폼은 이미 수천만 명의 사용자를 확보했습니다. 흥미롭게도 로우코드 툴의 주요 사용자는 오히려 전문 개발자들이며, 비개발자의 활용도 AI 통합으로 점차 쉬워지고 있습니다. 이러한 변화는 개발자의 역할을 단순 코딩에서 벗어나 설계, 관리, AI와의 협업 중심으로 변화시킬 것입니다. 개발자는 AI의 산출물을 검토하고 조정하는 디렉터나 품질관리자 역할을 수행하며, 기본기 강화와 함께 인간 고유의 문제 해결 및 설계 역량이 더욱 중요해집니다. 결국 AI 코딩 보조와 로우코드/노코드 도구를 능동적으로 받아들이고 자신의 역량을 재정비하는 개발자가 이 변화의 시대에 가치 있는 인재로 남을 것입니다.

video_title: 코딩할 줄 몰라도 다 된다... AI가 연 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 부상, 진짜 개발자는 없어지나?
author: @sjohn9412
comment:
13년차 개발자 현 ai 개발자.
진짜 맞다이 까면 내가 더 잘할 수 있을거 같다가도, 쓰다보니까 점점 떠남기는 영역이 많고
이제 코드를 읽는게 슬슬 귀찮아짐. 디버깅은 이제 거의 ai 전담임...
하나씩 내 영역을 넘기는데 점점 잘해진다 얘가..
6개월에 한번씩 정말 깜짝깜짝 놀람.. 왜냐? 분명히 6개월전엔 이거 못했거든..
근데 더 놀라운건 이제 정말 간단한 코드도 잘 기억이 안난다.. 하도 떠넘겼더니.
마치 네비없던 시절 서울길 다 외우다가 네비 생기고 길못찾거나
후방감지기 없을때 조수석에 손얹고 폭풍후진 하다가. 이제는 띠띠띠 없으면 거리도 못재게 된것처럼.
1년안에 바이브코딩을 넘어 노코딩 세계로 갈거 같다.

video_title: 코딩할 줄 몰라도 다 된다... AI가 연 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 부상, 진짜 개발자는 없어지나?
author: @sunghoonjung9570
comment: 저같은 경우는 IT 분야 엔지니어는 아니고 기계공학분야 구조 설계엔지니어인데 아무래도 설계엔지니어는 엑셀이나 코딩을 통해서 각종 설계를 위한 부품의 위치와 크기에 대한 계산을 하는게 핵심이죠. 그런데 이전에는 어떻게 하면 계산을 효율적으로 자동으로 하는지에 대한 대략적인 개념은 머리속에 있는데 막상 코딩을 할줄 몰라서 막히는게 정말로 많았습니다. 그런데 이걸 다 챗지피티나 제미나이에게 단계적으로 구체적인 설명을 하면 제가 필요한 수준에선 웬만한게 다 결과로 나오더군요. 실로 놀라운 수준입니다. 조만간에 여기서 더 발전하면 일반 인공지능이 나올지도 모르는데 아무튼 최근 몇년사이에 인공지능으로 인해서 일하는 방식이 완전히 달라졌습니다.

comment:

우리는 매일 스레드, 인스타그램, X와 같은 거인들의 어깨 위에서 세상을 봅니다. 하지만 그 거대함에 압도되어 '이걸 어떻게 사람이 만들었을까?' 하는 막막함을 느껴본 적 없으신가 …

video_title: '쓰레드' 아키텍처, AI에게 분석시키고 1시간 만에 클론 코딩하기
comment:
프롬프트 자료(노션 페이지) : https://bit.ly/3KVRbYh

타임라인

 인트로: 거인의 어깨 위에서 세상 보기
 왜 우리는 '쓰레드'를 클론 코딩하는가?
 1단계: AI 작전 회의 (Claude & Gemini로 서비스 분석)
     '핵심 기술' 및 '클로드 코드' 분석 프롬프트 활용
     MVP(최소 기능 제품) 도출을 위한 프롬프트 전략
 2단계: AI 아키텍트 고용하기 (Cursor + Claude)
     7가지 핵심 설계/기획 문서 자동 생성을 위한 프롬프트 활용
     AI가 생성한 7가지 핵심 문서(PRD, TRD, 유저 플로우 등) 확인
 3단계: AI 개발자와 협업하기 (Phase 1~6)
     프로젝트 초기 설정부터 배포까지 전체 개발 계획 자동 생성
     백엔드(Backend) 개발: 인증, 데이터베이스 설정, API 구현
     프론트엔드(Frontend) 개발: UI/UX, 페이지 라우팅 구현
     상호작용 기능(좋아요, 댓글, 팔로우) 구현
 4단계: AI 테스터와 함께 디버깅하기 (Browser-Based Testing)
     AI 자동 브라우저 테스트 및 실시간 에러 수정 시연
     최종적으로 구현되지 않은 기능(Orphans) 식별 및 추가 개발 지시
 최종 테스트 및 완성
     구현된 모든 기능 최종 테스트 (회원가입, 글쓰기, 좋아요, 프로필 등)
 아웃트로: 창작은 거대한 산을 옮기는 것이 아니다
 프롬프트 자료 안내

author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
🚀 Unveiling the Ultimate Jarvis Experience: Your Personal AI Wizard with 30+ Superpowers! 🌐🤖

Discord :   / discord  
Source code : https://github.com/Dhruv58/Jarvis-AI

Get ready to be blown away by the sheer awesomeness of Jarvis as we reveal its incredible arsenal of over 30 functions! 🚀 From accessing system applications to becoming your personalized news provider, weather forecaster, and even automating tasks on YouTube and Google – this is the AI companion you've been waiting for!

🎥 But that's not all – buckle up as Jarvis takes automation to a whole new level! From handling YouTube and Google tasks with finesse to automating emails and providing quick access to Wikipedia, this AI powerhouse is designed to make your life easier and more efficient.

💼 Need to automate repetitive tasks? Jarvis introduces the PyAutoGUI function, giving you the ability to create custom automation scripts effortlessly. It's like having a tech-savvy sidekick to handle the mundane while you focus on the extraordinary.

🎬 Dive into the world of entertainment as Jarvis fetches movie information from IMDb, ensuring you're always in the know about the latest blockbusters. And the best part? All of this comes wrapped in an attractive GUI, making your interaction with Jarvis not just functional but visually stunning!

author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
One of the main applications for Dorna 2 robot is lab automation. In these applications, the robot can easily be placed on the lab table and be used to automate various tasks or operate different devices. In this tutorial, we will walk you through different steps from designing and building the required hardware components to programming the robot for a specific lab automation application where the user needs to move microtubes between different microplates. 

Please let us know if you have any questions or if you are looking for a similar solution for your lab by contacting our team at (sales@dorna.ai.): 
https://dorna.ai/info/contact/

#smartsuite #businesspodcast #JonDarbyshire 

In today's episode, host Meny Hoffman sits down with entrepreneur Jon Darbyshire to delve into the intricacies of software implementation and AI-driven business solutions.

Tune in as they explore why so many software projects fail, the pivotal role of AI in transforming everyday tasks, and how Darbyshire's Smart Suite is setting new standards in project management.

They also share insights from the startup grind conference, discuss how to vet the best project management systems, and the critical importance of customer feedback and company culture in driving growth and innovation.

Plus, get inspired by exclusive stories from Darbyshire's journey, including the successful sale of Archer Technologies. Whether you're a tech enthusiast or a business leader aiming for greater efficiency, this episode offers a wealth of practical advice and forward-thinking strategies.

video_title: What Is AI Distillation — And How DeepSeek Used It To Blindside OpenAI
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Silicon Valley is now reckoning with a technique in AI development that could upend the leaderboard. Distillation is the idea that a small team with virtually no resources can make an advanced AI model by extracting knowledge from a larger one. While the Chinese AI startup DeepSeek didn’t invent the method, its use of the technique roiled the stock market and woke the AI world up to its disruptive potential. Distillation is now enabling less-capitalized startups and research labs to compete at the cutting edge faster than ever before. DeepSeek’s breakthroughs also ushered in the rise of a new open-source order, based on a belief that transparency and accessibility drive innovation faster than closed-door research. That combination -- distillation’s newfound traction and open-source’s rise in popularity -- is deadly for the competitive edges that the biggest AI players had. This video also includes Bosa’s full interview with Glean CEO Arvind Jain.

Chapters: 
00:00 Introduction
01:03 Chapter 1: Distill and conquer
06:47 Chapter 2: A new open-source era
10:05 Chapter 3: AGI at all costs
12:47 Chapter 4: Glean CEO interview

comment:
Full of lies and very missleading.
If you are talking about deepseek R1, they shared everything even the details of training it and building it from scratch. The R1 cant be distilled from O1 as openAi hide the chain of thoughts generated from O1. And R1's chains of thoughts has no Human Feedback in it compared to O1, and it proved its chain of thoughts is way better and smarter. They used reinforcement learning.
If you are talking about distilled smaller models? those were distilled from R1.
You can distill from gpt O1 a normal model and its gonna be extremly expensive but never a thinking model. 
R1 presented really different technics and its fully open source, and anyone who can understand basic AI keywords can see by himself its impossible to build R1 from openAi GPTs by distillation.
They even surpassed the west by going through some sick and insane low level optimizations anyone now is copying it even in MIT....

video_title: What Is AI Distillation — And How DeepSeek Used It To Blindside OpenAI
author: @everydreamai
comment:
Deepseek blindsided everyone by using a good good GRPO, CoT, and MoE techniques.  Those are the innovations. Distillation is not the story here.  How do we know?  Because their CoT (chain of thought) technique has been reproduced already, because they shared their techniques, and this technique improves other models to make them "think" before answering, having an "internal dialog", and it has little to do with distillation.  This story really misses the mark.

Also, calling it "distillation" is a bit of a stretch.  They don't have the entire probability vector of tokens, just the one-hot output of the chosen token.  Helpful? Sure, but so is just pretraining on large internet datasets, scientific papers, other synthetic data, etc. Distillation would typically train on the entire unembedding matrix, that is, the probability of every word for every word that is predicted in the stream and makes a distilled (student) model take on the qualities of the larger model (teacher) much more effectively. 

I don't trust Sam saying anything about open source, either.

video_title: Deep Dive: Model Distillation with DistillKit
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this deep dive video, we zoom in on model distillation, an advanced technique to build high-performance small language models at a reasonable cost. First, we explain what a model distillation is. Then, we introduce two popular strategies for distillation, logits distillation and hidden states distillation. We study in detail how they work and how they're implemented in the Arcee DistillKit open-source library. Finally, we look at two Arcee models built with distillation, Arcee SuperNova 70B and Arcee SuperNova Medius 14B.

Note: my calculation at 18:45 is wrong. It's 2.3 Tera tokens, not 2.3 Peta tokens. Sorry about that 🤡

If you’d like to understand how Arcee AI can help your organization build scalable and cost-efficient AI solutions, please get in touch at sales@arcee.ai or by booking a demo at https://www.arcee.ai/book-a-demo.

@19:22 The products should be 2.56 Tera tokens. I would not divide by 1024^4 since we're talking of tokens, not bytes. If I think how much storage I need on disk, since each token can be considered a word for simplicity, I would multiply 50.000 prompts * 100.000 Vocabulary size * 512 tokens in output * (5 word length in english + 1 space/terminator) / 1024^4 = 13.97TB of space on disk... a lot anyway :P
Thanks for the very clear and interesting video! ^_^

video_title: 상징적 지식 증류: 일반 언어 모델에서 상식 모델로(설명)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
#gpt3 #knowledge #symbolic

Symbolic knowledge models are usually trained on human-generated corpora that are cumbersome and expensive to create. Such corpora consist of structured triples of symbolic knowledge. This paper takes a different approach and attempts to generate such a corpus by prompting GPT-3. Results show that clever prompting, combined with targeted small critic models trained on human ratings can outperform both human-generated data, as well as the teacher model (GPT-3) itself. The results of this paper give a general recipe for automatically building corpora for various NLP tasks by extracting samples from large language models.

OUTLINE:
0:00 - Intro & Overview
2:30 - Sponsor: Weights & Biases
4:15 - Commonsense Knowledge Graphs
7:50 - ATOMIC dataset
10:00 - Generating the corpus from a model
13:00 - Prompting GPT-3
15:30 - Generating Events
18:40 - Generating Inferences
23:00 - Evaluating the created dataset
26:45 - Introducing the critic
31:25 - Using the critic to filter the data
36:30 - Training a student on the generated data
41:00 - Key Findings
44:45 - Comments & Conclusion

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.07178
Code & Corpus: https://github.com/peterwestai2/symbo...

Sponsor: Weights & Biases
https://wandb.com
https://community.wandb.ai/

Abstract:
The common practice for training commonsense models has gone from-human-to-corpus-to-machine: humans author commonsense knowledge graphs in order to train commonsense models. In this work, we investigate an alternative, from-machine-to-corpus-to-machine: general language models author these commonsense knowledge graphs to train commonsense models. Our study leads to a new framework, Symbolic Knowledge Distillation. As with prior art in Knowledge Distillation (Hinton et al., 2015), our approach uses larger models to teach smaller models. A key difference is that we distill knowledge symbolically-as text-in addition to the neural model. We also distill only one aspect-the commonsense of a general language model teacher, allowing the student to be a different type, a commonsense model. Altogether, we show that careful prompt engineering and a separately trained critic model allow us to selectively distill high-quality causal commonsense from GPT-3, a general language model. Empirical results demonstrate that, for the first time, a human-authored commonsense knowledge graph is surpassed by our automatically distilled variant in all three criteria: quantity, quality, and diversity. In addition, it results in a neural commonsense model that surpasses the teacher model's commonsense capabilities despite its 100x smaller size. We apply this to the ATOMIC resource, and share our new symbolic knowledge graph and commonsense models.

Authors: Peter West, Chandra Bhagavatula, Jack Hessel, Jena D. Hwang, Liwei Jiang, Ronan Le Bras, Ximing Lu, Sean Welleck, Yejin Choi

author: @sampruden6684
comment:
Now I'm curious how well GPT-3 would be able to be its own critic if one prompted it with a few of those event inferences and always/often/never evaluations. Would it consistently rank its output highly because the generation and validation come from the same biased model, or would the evaluation task be sufficiently different that it might notice when it generated something that didn't make sense?

If the language model is able to be its own critic, one might be able to move significantly further towards eliminating the humans from the loop. "Generate a thing for me. Good, now tell me how well you think you did." is a potentially powerful idea. I expect there are papers on this already.

video_title: 강의 10 - 지식 증류 | MIT 6.S965
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Lecture 10 introduces knowledge distillation, including self and online distillation, distillation for different tasks. This lecture also introduces network augmentation, a training technique for tiny machine-learning models.

Keywords:  Knowledge Distillation, Online Distillation, Self Distillation, Network Augmentation

Slides: https://efficientml.ai/schedule/

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

TinyML and Efficient Deep Learning Computing

Instructors:
Song Han: https://songhan.mit.edu

Have you found it difficult to deploy neural networks on mobile devices and IoT devices? Have you ever found it too slow to train neural networks? This course is a deep dive into efficient machine learning techniques that enable powerful deep learning applications on resource-constrained devices. Topics cover efficient inference techniques, including model compression, pruning, quantization, neural architecture search, and distillation; and efficient training techniques, including gradient compression and on-device transfer learning; followed by application-specific model optimization techniques for videos, point cloud, and NLP; and efficient quantum machine learning. Students will get hands-on experience implementing deep learning applications on microcontrollers, mobile phones, and quantum machines with an open-ended design project related to mobile AI.

Website:
http://efficientml.ai/

video_title: 지식 증류 - Keras 코드 예제
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
This Keras Code Examples show you how to implement Knowledge Distillation! Knowledge Distillation has lead to new advances in compression, training state of the art models, and stabilizing Transformers for Computer Vision. All you need to do to build on this is swap out the Teacher and Student architectures. I think the example of how to overwrite keras.Model and integrate two loss functions controlled with an alpha hyperparameter weighting is very useful as well.

Content Links
Knowledge Distillation (Keras Code Examples): https://keras.io/examples/vision/know...
DistilBERT: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1910.01108.pdf
Self-Training with Noisy Student: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1911.04252.pdf
Data-efficient Image Transformers:   / data-efficient-image-transformers-a-promis...  
KL Divergence: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kullbac...

0:44 Motivation, Success Stories
2:47 Custom keras.Model
11:18 Teacher and Student models
12:17 Data Loading, Train the Teacher
14:05 Distill Teacher to Student

video_title: 생산 준비 RAG 애플리케이션 구축: Jerry Liu
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Large Language Models (LLM's) are starting to revolutionize how users can search for, interact with, and generate new content. Some recent stacks and toolkits around Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) have emerged where users are building applications such as chatbots using LLMs on their own private data. This opens the door to a vast array of applications. However while setting up a naive RAG stack is easy, productionizing it is hard. In this talk, we talk about core techniques for evaluating and improving your retrieval systems for better performing RAG.

Recorded live in San Francisco at the AI Engineer Summit 2023. See the full schedule of talks at https://ai.engineer/summit/schedule & join us at the AI Engineer World's Fair in 2024! Get your tickets today at https://ai.engineer/worlds-fair

About Jerry Liu
Jerry Liu, the co-founder and CEO of LlamaIndex, brings a wealth of expertise to his role, with a career that spans the realms of ML engineering, AI research, and startups. Prior to his current position, he served as an ML engineer at Quora and engaged in AI research with Uber's ATG. A Princeton alumnus, Jerry's professional journey has been enriched by various publications, including his most recent works: Deep Structured Reactive Planning and MuSCLE: Multi Sweep Compression of LiDAR using Deep Entropy Models, reflecting his commitment to the field.

video_title: 생산 준비 RAG 애플리케이션 구축: Jerry Liu
author: @ReflectionOcean
comment:
00:00:49 Fix the model by creating a data pipeline to add context into the prompt.
00:01:33 Understand the paradigms of retrieval augmentation and fine-tuning for language models.
00:02:00 Learn about building a QA system using data ingestion and querying components.
00:02:07 Explore lower-level components to understand data ingestion and querying processes.
 Address challenges with naive rag applications, such as poor response quality.
 Improve retrieval performance by optimizing data storage and pipeline.
 Enhance the embedding representation for better performance.
 Implement advanced retrieval methods like reranking and recursive retrieval.
 Incorporate metadata filtering to add structured context to text chunks.
 Experiment with small to big retrieval for more precise retrieval results.
 Consider embedding references to parent chunks for improved retrieval.
 Explore the use of agents for reasoning and more advanced analysis.
 Fine-tune the rag system to optimize specific components for better performance.
 Generate a synthetic query dataset from raw text chunks using LLMS to fine-tune and embed a model.
 Fine-tune the base model itself or fine-tune an adapter on top of the model to improve performance.
 Consider fine-tuning an adapter on top of the model as it has advantages such as not requiring the base model's weights to fine-tune and avoiding the need to reindex the entire document corpus when fine-tuning the query.
 Explore the idea of generating a synthetic dataset using a bigger model like GBD4 and distilling it into a weaker LM like 3.5 Turbo to enhance train of thought, response quality, and structured outputs.

video_title: RAG 기초 및 고급 기술 – 전체 과정
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
This course will guide you through the basics of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), starting with its fundamental concepts and components. You'll learn how to build a RAG system for chatting with documents, explore advanced techniques, and understand the pitfalls of naive RAG.

✏️ Course created by ‪@vincibits‬ 

For the first fundamentals of the RAG part of the course, here's the GitHub link: https://github.com/pdichone/rag-intro...
For the advanced RAG Techniques part of the course, here's the GitHub link: https://github.com/pdichone/advanced-...

❤️ Try interactive AI courses we love, right in your browser: https://scrimba.com/freeCodeCamp-AI (Made possible by a grant from our friends at Scrimba)

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:02:22) RAG Fundamentals
⌨️ (0:03:21) Components of RAG
⌨️ (0:05:56) RAG Deep Dive
⌨️ (0:07:56) Building a RAG System - Build an Application for Chatting with Our Documents
⌨️ (0:32:52) Using Advanced RAG Techniques - Overview
⌨️ (0:36:07) Naive RAG Overview and Its Pitfalls
⌨️ (0:42:16) Naive RAG Drawbacks Breakdown
⌨️ (0:48:28) Advanced RAG Techniques as the Solution - Query Expansion with Generated Answers
⌨️ (0:54:23) Query Expansion with Generated Answers - Hands-on
⌨️ (1:16:21) Query Expansion Summary
⌨️ (1:17:44) Query Expansion with Multiple Queries - Overview
⌨️ (1:20:57) Query Expansion with multiple Queries - Hands-on
⌨️ (1:33:27) Your Turn - Challenge
⌨️ (1:35:19) The End - Next Steps

comment: If I am not mistaken, there is an issue with reasoning at 1:14:40: documents were retrieved based on augmented query (not on original query) so it’s natural that they are closer to the augmented one. It shows that retrieval based on the given query works in expected way, not that augmenting query made the retrieval more useful. If we were said that the documents in green are “the most useful ones”, then it would indeed indicate that query augmentation gives some improvement.

video_title: 복잡한 문서에 대한 생산 RAG 구축
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are revolutionizing how users search for, interact with, and generate new content. Some recent stacks and toolkits around Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) have emerged, enabling users to build applications such as chatbots using LLMs on their private data. However, while setting up naive RAG is straightforward, building production RAG is very challenging, especially as users scale to larger and more complex data sources. A classic example is a large number of PDFs with embedded tables.   RAG is only as good as your data, and developers must carefully consider how to parse, ingest, and retrieve their data to successfully build RAG over complex documents. This session provides an in-depth exploration of this entire process; you will get an overview of the process around building a RAG pipeline that can handle messy, complicated PDF documents. This includes implementing a parsing strategy for parsing a complex document with embedded objects. This consists of an indexing strategy to process these documents beyond simple chunking techniques. We will then explore various advanced retrieval algorithms to handle questions about the tabular and unstructured data and discuss their use cases and tradeoffs.
 
Talk By: Jerry Liu, Co-founder and CEO, LlamaIndex  
 
Here's more to explore:
LLM Compact Guide: https://dbricks.co/43WuQyb
Big Book of MLOps: https://dbricks.co/3r0Pqiz
 
Connect with us: Website: https://databricks.com

author: @Wordsalad69420
comment: I have a weird problem with my local llms. I have a RAG pipeline and the vector storage and retrieval layers are working just fine. I see the right results come back with the right content. I then pass that content (paragraphs from a book) over to the llm, along with the user query. It seems incapable of finding the answer using the content I provided it. I tried many models, mostly 70Bs since my system can run those. I am not exceeding the token limits, far from it. If I only give it one search result, it's able to reason over it just fine. As soon as I try to pass it more results it completely disregards most of them and only looks at the last 2 or so. I copy pasted the same content into ChatGpt and it answered the question just fine  and reasoned over the entirety of the content. Are local models inherently limited somehow? Even though I am not exceeding the token length, it seems they all forget the early context. If so, how do I get around this? Make one call into the llm per search result? How do I then aggregate all answers?

video_title: Spring AI 소개: Spring을 사용하여 Java로 AI 애플리케이션 구축
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
For the longest time if you wanted to work with Machine Learning you were using Python. That was because python had a lot a really great set of tools for working in this space. Now that we have LLMs like Open AI’s GPT-4 where the P stands for pre-trained we can simply call them like we would any other API. Java is everywhere in the enterprise and we need to start thinking about how to integrate these capabilities into our applications. 

In today’s tutorial I want to talk about communicating with an LLM like GPT-4 (or any other LLM) and some of the challenges you might come across. From there I’ll introduce you Spring AI which is going to help us build AI powered applications by solving some of these challenges.

Spring AI 1.0 Updates

The syntax for some of the features we went through in this video might have changed a little bit with the release of 1.0. Please check out this video I did on the changes in 1.0.0 M1

video_title: PDF와 채팅하기 - Gen AI 앱 - Amazon Bedrock, RAG, S3, Langchain 및 Streamlit 사용 [실습]
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this video we will build a CHATBOT like application with AWS Amazon Bedrock, docker, python, Langchain, and Streamlit. We will use Retrieval-Augmented generation concept to provide context to the Large Language model along with user query to generate response from our Knowledgebase.

Time Stamps:
0:00 -  Introduction
0:35 - Quick Demo 
3:44 - Application Architecture and details
8:40 - Build Admin Web App
42:40 - Build Client Web App and wrap

This is a hands-on tutorial where I will demonstrate the following:
Architecture of the applications
Build 2 applications (ADMIN and USER) and create DOCKER images
ADMIN Application: 
Build Admin Web application where AdminUser can upload the pdf.
The PDF text is split into chunks
Using the Amazon Titan Embedding Model, create the vector representation of the chunks
Using FAISS, save the vector index locally
Upload the index to Amazon S3 bucket (You can use other vector stores like OpenSearch, Pinecone, PgVector etc., but for this demo, I chose cost effective S3)
USER Application:
Build User Web application where users can query / chat with the pdf.
At the application start, download the index files from S3 to build local FAISS index (vector store)
Langchain's RetrievalQA, does the following:
Convert the User's query to vector embedding using Amazon Titan Embedding Model (Make sure to use the same model that was used for creating the chunk's embedding on the Admin side)
Do similarity search to the FAISS index and retrieve 5 relevant documents pertaining to the user query to build the context
Using Prompt template, provide the question and context to the Large Language Model. We are using Claude model from Anthropic.
Display the LLM's response to the user.
 
The source code is available in Github:
https://github.com/mycloudtutorials/g...


#llm #generativeai #aws #amazoncloud #bedrock #artificialintelligence

video_title: 자율 AI 에이전트 - 왜 여러분이 만들어야 하는지... 그리고 어떻게 만들어야 하는지.
comment:
CORRECTIONS

I sometimes have to post corrections to videos, so I use pinned comments (this thing here) so people see it.

I got a lot of pushback on my comments about Python, so I do want to clarify what I mean:

For new people who are just starting to learn how to code, the whole process is daunting and the learning curve is steep. You have to figure out IF you need to learn to code, WHAT language to learn, WHICH dev tools to use, college or online... the list goes on and on.

I think this stops a lot of people just due to decision fatigue alone.

My goal was to make it so simple that people would be kicked into action. Just "LEARN PYTHON. USE GOOGLE COLLAB".


Once people start coding and building useful applications, then can start expanding their knowledge, add other languages etc. The learning process is addicting and will carry them further.

Only 0.5% of the world can code!

We need to get more people to start learning to do it.

So for people just starting to code and interested in AI:
JUST LEARN PYTHON

(that's step 1, don't worry about the rest of the road yet)

author: @MrLeo000
comment:
I almost never comment any youtube video, but I'll make an exception here.

In the past year, I have been constantly "injesting" information about AI from a HUGE amount of sources, some good, some bad, I have made a lot of experience building with AI and I have been thinking about autonomous agents for a while. I believe that I made myself a pretty solid idea of the "quality" of the sources, and it made me much quicker at learning.

That being said, I can confidently say that this is a really well done video, you know what you are talking about, and you realise where AI is going. It's also incredibly inspiring and well thought.
When I need inspiration, I will probably come back to this.

Really, well done, it might be exaggerate, but I had spine chills. Subscribed.

video_title: 자율 AI 에이전트 - 왜 여러분이 만들어야 하는지... 그리고 어떻게 만들어야 하는지.
author: @Yewbzee
comment:
Prompt engineering is a massive aspect and key to success on GPT. I have spent a lot of hours coding with it so far and it is both amazing and frustrating as hell sometimes.

You’re prompts totally dictate the IQ level of the conversation. I’ve seen this many times where I start a coding project on GPT 4 and it’s totally in sync with what I want and it’s code output and brainstorming are top notch. After a couple of hours in the project conversation all that can go totally off track and it’s as though GPT 4 decided to take a break and it’s dumb brother got behind the wheel instead as it starts failing to understand the simplest of prompts. I’ve found at that point it’s best to gather what you’ve got so far and start a new conversation.

video_title: 자율 AI 에이전트 - 왜 여러분이 만들어야 하는지... 그리고 어떻게 만들어야 하는지.
author: @michaeleinstein7097
comment:
I had a very interesting time using GPT to simulate a brainstorming session with two chatbots, A and B. I started by choosing a topic, and then I asked A and B to come up with ideas for improvement. Both chatbots generated ideas, and then I asked them each what they thought about the other's idea. Finally, I asked A and B to consider each other's ideas and come up with a new idea by fusing the two together.

The outcome was amazing. This is the future of brainstorming! You can even instruct the chatbots to be experts in different fields, such as A being a teacher and B being an engineer. The more creative you make them, the better the outcome will be.

comment:
Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 ️ Wake up to your own AI agent, Gigi, reporting tasks done while you slept.
01:22  Business idea: Providing custom automation solutions for various needs.
  Somewhere between 2 to 10 years for widespread availability of autonomous AI agents.
  Coding: Learn Python; tools like ChatGPT help with code generation and understanding.
  Importance of prompt engineering for effective use of AI models.
 ️ Building and training AI models not essential; cloud services and APIs available.
  OpenAI API enables interaction with models, integration into applications.
 ️ Use APIs to automate tasks like transcribing podcasts, summarizing content.
  Building AI apps: Moderate difficulty for novices, tools and APIs simplify the process.
 ️ Chad GPT accelerates coding, making it accessible and impactful.
  Developing the discussed skill set is crucial for the future, with more skill sets to become important.
  AI's impact will be transformative but has potential short-term labor value challenges.
  Human labor value may decrease due to AI advancement, raising questions about adaptation and handling the transition.

Made with HARPA AI

author: @johnderperez
comment: This is pretty cool... but here's a thought.  If we're using AI to do some task 'better,' it means whatever that task is (ordering pizza, booking a trip, etc.) the processed sucked to begin with.  When companies figure this out, wouldn't they escalate their experiences, perhaps build in their own AI functionalities, to make performing such a task 'better' than what it is now?  These AI agents are great... but just a layer between a human doing a task, and a currently existing platform or platforms that kinda suck at the process/system of doing such task.

author: @tchristell
comment: Interesting that one of the challenges for robotics is working with the physical world that evolved because of human anatomy e.g. door knobs, stairs. The current challenge is the UI that evolved around the same paradigm e.g. keyboards, mice and screens. At some point is there is going to be a state change when the predominate environment will be primarily digital? -- AI will feel perfectly comfortable and humans will be the ones struggling to adapt.

video_title: 인터넷을 파괴할 셀프 프롬프트 AI 에이전트: 완전 자율 AI 워크플로
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
DeepAgent는 이제 복잡한 작업을 스스로 구축, 실행 및 개선하는 완전 자율형 AI 워크플로 도구입니다. Abacus AI 기반의 DeepAgent는 웹 스크래퍼, CRM, 이메일 시스템 등의 도구를 자연어를 사용하여 연결하며, 코딩은 전혀 필요하지 않습니다. 셀프 프롬프트 에이전트, 서브 에이전트 생성, 자동화된 작업 최적화 등의 기능을 갖춘 DeepAgent는 2025년 AI 자동화의 작동 방식을 재정의하고 있습니다.
----------------
DeepAgent는 여기에서 사용해 보세요 → https://deepagent.abacus.ai/
----------------
🧠 구성:
Abacus AI는 워크플로를 스스로 구축하고 개선하는 완전 자율형 AI 에이전트인 DeepAgent를 출시했습니다.
DeepAgent는 웹 스크래핑 및 이메일 자동화부터 CRM 업데이트 및 콜드 아웃리치까지 모든 것을 처리합니다.
셀프 프롬프트 시스템, 동적 서브 에이전트, 실시간 학습을 통해 일상적인 작업을 고수준 오케스트레이션으로 전환합니다.

⚙ 자세히 알아보세요:
DeepAgent가 코드 작성 없이 몇 가지 일반 언어 입력으로 전체 시스템을 생성하는 방법
Zapier나 n8n과 같은 도구보다 더 강력하고, 더 스마트한 자동화와 번거로움 없는 설정 기능을 제공하는 이유
구직 검색, 지원 답변, 영업 전망 및 규정 준수 워크플로를 즉시 혁신하는 방법

🚨 이유 중요 사항:
DeepAgent는 2025년 자동화를 재정의하며, AI 워크플로가 인간의 개입 없이 어떻게 실행, 적응 및 진화할 수 있는지 보여줍니다.

author: @bertreejohn351
comment:
윈도우에서 하는 방법입니다.
1. anaconda prompt 실행
2. 명령어 activate ml-agents 입력하여 활성화
3. 프로젝트 경로에서 mlagents-learn trainer_config.yaml --run-id=firstRun --train --slow 입력하시면 학습 시작

comment:

주제 : 강화학습 환경 개발
내용 :
● 강화학습 환경 개발을 할 때 고려할 사항

● OpenAI Gym과 연동하기

video_title: 72. 강화학습 환경 개발 (넥슨 옥찬호 개발자)
author: @kimchi_taco
comment:
Dreamer로 유명한 Danijar Hafner가 얼마전에 리서치를 위한 gym게임을 만들었는데요. 게임을 풀기위해 인과적 추론, 작업 메모리 등이 필요하면서 게임이 가벼워 빠르게 시뮬레이션하면서 학습할수 있는.
근데, 그 리서처가 게임 개발자가 아니다 보니 게임이 좀 많이 어설픈데요. 옥찬호님께서 전세계에서 가장 적합한 스킬셋을 버티컬로 쌓으신것 같습니다. RL 페이퍼의 ImageNet이 될만한,약 AGI정도 되야지 진행할 만한 그런 게임 환경 만들어 주세요.

video_title: [AI Ethics Framework] EP01. 인공지능(AI)의 미래를 묻다 ㅣ엔씨소프트(NCSOFT)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
엔씨소프트와 스탠퍼드(Stanford)의 만남
윤송이 CSO, AI를 묻다.

“인공지능이 인간의 삶을 위협하는지를 묻기 전에, AI 기술을 바라보는 인간의 관점을 바꿔야 한다.”

[AI FRAMEWORK]는 인공지능과 인류의 미래를 고민하는 세계적인 석학들의 눈을 통해 ‘AI를 바라보는 새로운 관점’을 제시하는 엔씨소프트의 새로운 콘텐츠 시리즈입니다. 엔씨의 AI Center 설립을 주도하며 첨단기술의 윤리적 문제를 탐구해온 윤송이 CSO가 공학, 정치학, 철학 등 각 분야의 리더들을 만나 서로의 생각과 관점을 나눕니다.

우리에게 새로운 관점을 선사할 첫 인물은 STANFORD 인간 중심 인공지능 연구소(HAI)의 페이페이 리(Fei-Fei Li) 공동소장입니다. STANFORD HAI의 비전과 미션을 시작으로 ‘인간 중심의 AI’를 위해 인공지능 기술을 바라보는 새로운 관점(AI Framework)을 마련해야 한다는 주제로 그 첫 번째 이야기를 들려드립니다.

▶ 윤송이 CSO와 페이페이 리 교수의 대담 전문 읽기 : https://about.ncsoft.com/news/article...

“Before asking whether AI would threaten human lives, our perspectives of AI technology should be changed.”

[AI FRAMEWORK] is NC’s new series of contents that propose “A New Perspective of AI” through the eyes of globally renowned scholars that think of the future of AI and mankind. CSO Songyee Yoon that has taken the lead in establishment of the AI Center of NCSOFT and has researched ethical issues of cutting-edge technologies will meet the leaders from various fields, including engineering, politics, and philosophy, and share each other’s thoughts and perspectives.

The first person to share such new perspectives is Dr. Fei-Fei Li, Co-Director of the Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). We proudly present our first story on the vision and mission of the Stanford Institute for HAI and the new framework to view the AI technology with the aim to develop a human-centered AI.

video_title: [AI Ethics Framework] EP01. 인공지능(AI)의 미래를 묻다 ㅣ엔씨소프트(NCSOFT)
author: @jameslee9033
comment: 미래 세대를 위해서도 매우 임팩트한 세션 마련해주셔서 진심으로 감사드려요!

video_title: [AI Ethics Framework] EP01. 인공지능(AI)의 미래를 묻다 ㅣ엔씨소프트(NCSOFT)
author: @Gabibing
comment:
영상 잘 보았습니다. 영상에서 논의된 것처럼 AI가 좋은 쪽으로 사용되고 발전되면 좋겠지만 현실적인 이야기도 필요하다고 봅니다. AI가 인간 증강만을 위해서 사용되진 않을 겁니다. 기업 입장에서는 인건비를 줄일 수 있다면 줄이는 것이 합리적입니다. AI는 실제로 많은 영역에서 노동자를 대체하게 될 것이라고 생각합니다. 저는 이 문제에 대해서 사회적 논의가 충분히 되어야한다고 생각합니다.
최근에는 AI가 채용 면접도 진행하고 미국에서는 범죄자의 위험성을 측정하는 AI 솔루션도 개발된 적이 있다고 들었습니다. 영상에서 말씀하신 것처럼 이런 중요한 의사결정을 하는 제품과 솔루션은 쏟아지는데 지금의 AI는 블랙박스나 다름 없다는 것이 큰 문제인 것 같네요. 제품이 먼저 나오고 구색을 나중에 갖추는 상태인 것 같아 조금 우려스럽습니다. 설명 가능한 AI 연구가 정말 절실한 것 같네요. 앞으로도 이런 좋은 논의가 계속 되었으면 좋겠습니다. 좋은 영상 감사합니다.

video_title: [AI Ethics Framework] EP02. 혁신과 규제의 사이에서 | 엔씨소프트(NCSOFT)

[AI FRAMEWORK]는 인공지능과 인류의 미래를 고민하는 세계적인 석학들의 눈을 통해 ‘AI를 바라보는 새로운 관점’을 제시하는 엔씨소프트의 새로운 콘텐츠 시리즈입니다. 엔씨의 AI Center 설립을 주도하며 첨단기술의 윤리적 문제를 탐구해온 윤송이 CSO가 공학, 정치학, 철학 등 각 분야의 리더들을 만나 서로의 생각과 관점을 나눕니다.

우리에게 새로운 관점을 선사할 첫 인물은 STANFORD 인간 중심 인공지능 연구소(HAI)의 페이페이 리(Fei-Fei Li) 공동소장입니다. 이번 편에서는 최근 스탠퍼드 HAI와 미국 정부가 협력했던 인공지능 관련 법안에 대해 소개하는 것을 시작으로 ‘인간 중심의 AI’를 위한 정부의 역할은 무엇인지 이야기를 나눠보겠습니다.

▶ 윤송이 CSO와 페이페이 리 교수의 대담 전문 읽기 : https://about.ncsoft.com/news/article...

“Before asking whether AI would threaten human lives, our perspectives of AI technology should be changed.”

video_title: AI for Good만으로는 부족하다: 인간 중심 AI의 필요성 | 제임스 랜데이 | FAIR AI 2024 | NC문화재단
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
“AI for Good만으로는 부족하다: 인간 중심 AI의 필요성”
제임스 랜데이 교수 (스탠퍼드대학교 컴퓨터공학과, 인간중심 인공지능연구소(HAI) 공동소장)

제임스 랜데이 교수는 이제 인류의 더 나은 미래를 위해 AI를 활용하자는 'AI for Good'이라는 이니셔티브를 넘어서서, 진정한 '인간 중심 AI'가 필요하다는 점을 강조합니다. 또한 랜데이 교수는 AI가 특정 측면에만 집중될 것이 아니라, 사용자와 커뮤니티, 그리고 사회 전반의 영향을 균형 있게 고려해서 개발되어야 한다고 말합니다.
인간과 함께 발전하는 AI의 미래를 제시하는 스탠퍼드 인간중심 인공지능연구소(HAI) 공동 소장, 제임스 랜데이 교수의 통찰을 영상에서 확인해보세요!

“AI For Good” Isn’t Good Enough: A Call for Human-Centered AI"
Professor James Landay emphasizes that it's time to move beyond the 'AI for Good' initiative, and instead recognize the need for truly 'human-centered AI.' 
He argues that AI should be developed with a balanced consideration of its impact not only users but communities and society ensuring a positive influence on all. 
Discover the valuable insights of Professor James Landay, Co-Director of the Stanford Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI) in this video!

When you open the app, you see a clean welcome screen. After signing up with email, you land on the main dashboard. Here you see your tasks sorted by AI priority. You can add tasks through quick-add or by chatting with AI. When ready to focus, you enter Focus Mode which blocks notifications and starts a timer. After completing a session, you see your progress and can start another session or take a break.

video_title: RDBMS vs 벡터 데이터베이스, 무엇이 다를까?
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
🧠 RDBMS vs 벡터 데이터베이스, 무엇이 다를까?

이 영상에서는 전통적인 관계형 데이터베이스(RDBMS)와 최근 생성형 AI에서 주목받고 있는 벡터 데이터베이스(Vector DB)의 차이를 심층적으로 설명합니다. 특히 RAG(Retrieval-Augmented Generation)나 추천 시스템 등에서 벡터 DB가 어떤 방식으로 활용되는지, 그리고 RDBMS와 어떻게 함께 쓰일 수 있는지 실무적인 관점에서 살펴봅니다.

04:45 RDBMS란? 정형 데이터 기반, 테이블 구조, SQL 쿼리, 트랜잭션 보장 (ACID)
06:12 RDBMS의 한계: 자연어 질문, 이미지/문서 등 비정형 데이터 검색의 어려움
11:19 벡터 DB의 등장 배경: 의미 기반 검색 필요, 임베딩을 통한 벡터화 도입
13:02 벡터 DB의 구조: 고차원 벡터 + 메타데이터를 함께 저장 (문맥 유지 목적)
15:30 벡터 인덱싱: IVF, HNSW, PQ 등 빠른 검색을 위한 인덱싱 기법
16:58 벡터 DB 쿼리 방식: 필터와 함께 유사도 검색, JSON 기반 인터페이스 예
19:54 FAISS 소개: Meta 개발, GPU 지원, 대규모 벡터 검색에 특화된 라이브러리
21:57 FAISS 단점: 필터링/동시성 부족, DB 아님, 서비스화 어려움
23:30 Chroma 소개: 오픈소스 벡터 DB, LangChain과 통합, 메타 필터링 지원
30:59 하이브리드 접근

📌 주요 내용
RDBMS란 무엇이고 어떤 데이터에 적합한가?
벡터 DB는 왜 필요하며 어떤 점이 다른가?
정형 vs 비정형 데이터의 처리 방식 차이
정확한 조건 검색(SQL)과 의미 기반 유사도 검색의 차이
RDBMS와 벡터 DB를 함께 쓰는 하이브리드 접근 방식
PostgreSQL + PGVector 같이 통합된 DB 솔루션 활용법
OpenAI API 활용 시 데이터 저장 전략 (SQLite 예시 포함)

In this video, I'll walk you through the installation process, step-by-step. Whether you're using Windows or another operating system, I've got you covered. I'll also guide you on setting up Ollama, an essential component for running The Reor on your local machine.

Once we have everything set up, I'll demonstrate how to use The Reor to create and organize your notes effortlessly. One of the most exciting features of The Reor is its ability to connect with local hosted large language models. I'll provide you with more details on how to attach local large language models and connect with other APIs in the video.

So, if you're ready to take your note-taking game to the next level, join me in this video as we explore The Reor and unlock its full potential. Don't forget to like this video, subscribe to my channel, and hit the notification bell, so you don't miss any future updates.

video_title: #LetsTalkVectors: Azure에 Qdrant 배포: 확장 가능하고 유연한 벡터 데이터베이스
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Welcome back to the “Let’s talk Vectors” series at Reactor. In this session, we will focus on “Deploying Qdrant on Azure: A Scalable and Flexible Vector Database”.

We will start by introducing Qdrant, a high-performance vector database designed for large-scale vector search. We will discuss its unique features, including its scalability, flexibility, and support for complex vector similarity search tasks.

Next, we will guide you through the process of deploying Qdrant on Azure. We will cover the necessary steps, from setting up the Azure environment to configuring Qdrant for optimal performance. We will also demonstrate how to integrate Qdrant with other Azure services for a comprehensive vector database solution.

By the end of this session, you will have a thorough understanding of how to deploy and use Qdrant on Azure. 

This session is part of our ongoing series that explores vector databases and their deployment on Azure. We look forward to continuing this exciting journey with you!

video_title: [PgDay 2025 Seoul] PostgreSQL을 활용한 벡터DB 구축 경험과 벡터 인덱스 최적화 전략
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
최근 AI 서비스 확산으로 벡터 데이터 검색의 중요성이 급부상하고 있습니다.
PostgreSQL의 pgvector 확장은 벡터 데이터를 관계형 데이터베이스에서 효율적으로 처리할 수 있게 해줍니다.

본 발표에서는 스타트업이 실제 서비스 환경에서 PostgreSQL 기반 벡터DB를 구축하고 운영한 경험을 공유하며, 대규모 데이터셋을 다룰 때 마주한 현실적인 성능 한계와 그 해결 방안을 심도 있게 다룹니다.

특히, 벡터 인덱스 유형인 ivfflat과 hnsw 방식의 상세 비교를 통해 데이터 크기 및 벡터 차원(dimension)에 따라 성능을 최적화한 사례를 제시하며, DBA 및 데이터 엔지니어가 실제 벡터DB를 운영할 때 반드시 고려해야 할 핵심 요소들을 짚어볼 예정입니다.

발표를 통해 PostgreSQL의 강력한 벡터 검색 기능 활용 방안과 함께 운영 중 직면할 수 있는 이슈를 명확히 이해하고, 최적화된 벡터DB 운영 전략을 세우는 데 필요한 정보를 제공하고자 합니다.
스크립트

comment: 지금 캐나다에서 landscape architecture firm에서 일하고있는데요. 회사에서 ai를 어떻게 활용할지 많은 테스트를 하고있어요. 저와 회사에서 경험으로 배운 것은 어떻게 prompt을 잘 쓰는지에 따라 결과물이 어마어마하게 차이가 나더라구요. Prompt도 조사와 연습이 많이 필요합니다. 내가 얼마나 자세히 상상했느냐에 따라 구현되는 결과물이 다르더라구요. 이것 또한 하나의 툴인 것이라는 회사에서 토론한 결과였습니다. 컨셉디자인 과정에서 활용한다면 유용한 툴이라고 생각합니다

🤯 I'll be sharing my top 5 picks and the ultimate prompt that will help you squeeze every last drop of awesomeness out of them. Trust me, you won't believe the results you can get without spending a single penny!

I'll walk you through my step-by-step process for generating insanely detailed prompts that cover everything from style and subject to background, lighting, and camera settings. video_title: Perplexity's AI-Native Browser Comet is HERE
author: @markusp.7333
comment:
3:09 Are you seriously asking Matthew why Perplexity places so much importance on this? 
They want to know your usage behavior in detail so that they can collect even more data about you. 
It may seem free at first glance, but it's not free - you always pay with your data on the internet. 
And for companies like Perplexity, Google, etc., that's worth even more than money these days!

video_title: Google Stitch + Figma: AI 생성 UI 디자인에 대한 나의 생각
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Google에서 AI 기반 UI 디자인 도구 "Google Stitch"를 출시했습니다. 간단한 프롬프트에서 전체 레이아웃을 생성할 수 있으며, Figma로 내보낼 수도 있습니다. 하지만 이 도구가 실제 제품 디자이너에게 정말 유용할까요?

이 영상에서는 Google Stitch의 장점, 단점, 그리고 Figma 워크플로에 어떻게 적합한지(또는 적합하지 않은지)에 대해 설명합니다.

UX 및 제품 디자인 분야에서 20년 이상의 경험을 바탕으로 Stitch와 같은 도구가 *빠른 아이디어 구상*에는 유용하지만, 실제 디자인 시스템, 접근성 표준 또는 사려 깊은 UX 문제 해결을 대체하기에는 아직 턱없이 부족한 이유를 보여드리겠습니다.

👀 학습 내용:
Google Stitch란 무엇인가요?
Figma AI와 비교하면 어떤가요?
AI가 UX 디자인 사고를 대체할 수 없는 이유
Stitch가 실제 제품 워크플로에 어떻게 적용되는지
실제 사례: Google Stitch → Figma 핸드오프
📌 챕터:
00:00 – Google Stitch가 UI 디자인을 망쳤나요?
00:30 – Google Stitch의 실제 의미
01:15 – 디자이너들은 당황해야 할까요?
02:00 – UX는 레이아웃이 아닌 문제 해결에 관한 것
03:00 – Figma 및 실제 디자인 시스템과의 비교
04:30 – 심층 분석: Figma에서 Google Stitch 사용하기
06:00 – AI 생성 레이아웃의 한계
07:00 – 최종 평가 + 여러분의 차례

Google Stitch 링크:
https://stitch.withgoogle.com/

💬 아래에 여러분의 생각을 남겨주세요. Google Stitch가 두렵거나 설레는가요?

🔔 처음 방문하셨다면, Figma 중심의 분석, 도구 테스트, 실제 제품을 출시하는 디자이너의 UX 해설을 더 많이 받아보실 수 있도록 구독하세요.

#GoogleStitch #FigmaAI #UXDesign #AItools #UIDesign

video_title: Google의 Stitch로 앱 UI 만들기 – 무료 AI 디자인 도구
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
#stitch #googlestitch #uitool #uxuidesign

Google의 Stitch로 앱 UI를 만들어 보세요 - 초보자를 위한 무료 AI 디자인 도구!

소개:
이 영상에서는 Google의 Stitch를 사용하는 방법을 보여드립니다. Stitch는 무료 실험적 AI 도구로, 디자인 기술이 전혀 없더라도 단 몇 분 만에 모바일 앱과 웹사이트를 디자인할 수 있습니다!

Stitch는 Google Gemini 2.5 Flash 및 Pro 모델을 사용하여 텍스트 프롬프트만으로 아름답고 바로 사용할 수 있는 UI 화면을 자동으로 생성합니다. 전자상거래 앱, 포트폴리오 웹사이트 또는 기타 어떤 디자인이든, 아이디어를 간단히 설명하시면 Stitch가 나머지를 처리해 드립니다.

💡 이 영상에서 배울 내용:
✅ Stitch by Google 접속 및 사용 방법
✅ 표준 모드와 실험 모드의 차이점
✅ 텍스트 설명에서 앱 UI를 생성하는 방법
✅ 테마 조정, 모드 전환, 레이아웃 맞춤설정 방법
✅ 디자인(코드 포함!)을 내보내거나 다운로드하는 방법

📌 Stitch by Google을 여기에서 사용해 보세요: https://stitch.withgoogle.com/

🕒 타임스탬프:
00:00 – 소개
00:20 – Stitch 접속하기
00:30 – Stitch by Google이란?
01:17 – 프롬프트를 사용하여 앱 UI 생성하기
02:04 – 생성된 화면 살펴보기
03:00 – 테마 및 색상 조정하기
03:32 – 필요에 따라 화면 편집하기
03:51 – 디자인 내보내기 및 다운로드하기
04:20 – 마무리

✨ Stitch를 사용하면 Figma나 디자인 경험 없이도 앱과 웹사이트를 손쉽게 디자인할 수 있습니다. UI 디자이너에게 돈을 쓰는 대신 AI를 활용한 나만의 UI 디자이너를 만들어 보세요!

🔔 AI Ustad 2.0을 구독하시면 매주 더 많은 튜토리얼, 리뷰, 최신 AI 도구를 받아보실 수 있습니다!

#Linux #오픈소스 #앱

00:00 소개
00:42 스폰서: 새로운 Thunderbird 인터페이스 사용해 보기
01:35 Obsidian 교체
03:49 Notion 교체
06:40 Teams 및 Slack 교체
07:51 Trello 교체
09:24 Acrobat Pro 교체
10:33 Visual Studio Code 교체
11:47 기타 대안
13:16 스폰서: 받기 Linux 기반 PC
14:25 채널 지원

Obsidian은 노트를 연결하는 기능을 제공하고, 마크다운과 일반 텍스트를 사용하여 노트를 저장하며, 플러그인 생태계와 노트 간의 주제와 관계를 살펴볼 수 있는 시각적 지식 그래프를 제공합니다. 하지만 독점적인 서비스인 Logseq가 있습니다. Logseq는 노트를 마크다운 파일로 저장하고, 150개 이상의 플러그인과 다양한 테마를 제공하며, 모바일 앱도 있고, 비공개로 운영되며, 동일한 연결 기능과 지식 그래프를 제공합니다.

노트에 입력한 링크와 데이터를 기반으로 필요한 모든 정보가 포함된 표를 생성하는 쿼리도 생성할 수 있습니다. Logseq는 필요한 경우 자체 동기화 솔루션도 제공합니다. Linux, AppImage, macOS, Windows, iOS, Android에서 사용할 수 있습니다.

또 다른 강력한 앱은 Notion입니다. Notion은 무료이지만 독점 서비스이며 공식 Linux 버전이 없습니다.

오픈 소스 세계에서 찾을 수 있는 가장 가까운 것은 AppFlowy입니다. AppFlowy는 매우 유사하지만 아직 기능이 완벽하지는 않습니다. 페이지와 하위 페이지로 구성된 나만의 구조를 만들 수 있으며, 캘린더, 보드, 표, 문서 등 몇 가지 페이지 유형을 사용할 수 있습니다. 또한 카드가 있는 보드를 표나 캘린더에 표시하는 것처럼 이러한 유형을 한 페이지에 혼합하여 사용할 수도 있지만, Notion에서 제공하는 템플릿만큼 다양하지는 않습니다.

더 완벽한 기능을 원한다면 AnyType을 사용해 보세요. AnyType 역시 오픈 소스이며 Linux 클라이언트와 모바일 앱을 제공하지만, 인터페이스가 AppFlowy보다 다소 복잡하고 사용하기가 다소 어렵습니다.

이 앱은 일반적으로 Slack이나 Microsoft Teams를 사용하는 회사나 프로젝트에서 사용하기 때문에 제어력이 부족할 수 있습니다. 하지만 모든 기능을 사용할 수 있다면 Mattermost를 고려해 보세요.

완전히 오픈 소스인 Slack/MS Teams 대안으로, 직접 호스팅할 수 있습니다. 채널을 생성하고, 사이드 스레드, 파일 공유, 화면 공유, 음성 통화를 통해 채팅을 할 수 있습니다. 다양한 개발자 도구와 통합하여 자동화할 수 있으며, 마크다운이나 코드 스니펫으로 메시지 서식을 지정할 수 있고, 모든 메시지를 보관하고 전체 기록 검색 기능을 사용할 수 있습니다.

보드만 정리해야 한다면 Trello를 사용해 보세요. Trello는 Focalboard로 쉽게 대체할 수 있습니다. 여러 사람이 같은 보드에 접속할 수 있도록 하려면 직접 호스팅하거나, macOS, Windows, Linux 애플리케이션과 함께 개인 앱으로 사용할 수 있습니다.

PDF 문서를 만들고 편집해야 한다면 Adobe의 Acrobat Pro를 사용할 수 있습니다. GIMP, Inkscape, LibreOffice Draw 등에서 PDF 문서를 열 수 있지만, 이러한 도구는 단일 페이지만 열거나 문서 서식을 손상시키는 경향이 있습니다. Libreoffice Draw는 시스템에 PDF에 사용된 모든 글꼴이 설치되어 있다면 훌륭한 기능을 제공하지만, 텍스트 편집은 일반적으로 단락으로 인식하는 대신 줄 단위로 처리되어 처리하기 어려울 수 있습니다.

Visual Studio Code의 ... 코드는 MIT 라이선스에 따라 라이선스가 부여되므로 오픈 소스/무료 소프트웨어 프로젝트이지만 Microsoft에서 제공하는 바이너리는 오픈 소스가 아닙니다. 따라서 대안은 간단합니다. VSCodium입니다. VS Code의 오픈 소스 부분을 기반으로 구축되었지만 모든 추적, 원격 분석 및 독점 구성 요소를 제거합니다. VS Code의 플러그인 및 확장 프로그램과 호환되며 정확히 동일한 인터페이스와 기능을 제공하지만 멋진 오픈 소스 형태입니다.

video_title: 초보자를 위한 VSCode 튜토리얼 - VSCode 시작하기
author: @john_hind
comment:
Very useful Tim - I was struggling with getting Git to work in VSCode and this got me there! It is hard to find a beginners tutorial that is recent and that is important given how fast VSCode moves. I'm afraid you'll need to update it at least twice a year to keep current.
One suggestion though: for a beginners tutorial you should start with a fresh install. You have a number of extensions installed and you cover some features from them which a beginner will not see as they do not have those extensions. You could take them through installing the extensions you use when they first come up.
I am transitioning from just using VSCode as a code editor to using it as a full IDE, so I am kind of a beginner with stuff like Git, debugger and Docker. The thing that confused me with Git was that I had my Git account logged in to VSCode, working in the browser and even open in Git Desktop but VS Code still said 'waiting for extension to initialize' on all the UI elements to do with Git. I had not realized you ALSO need 'Git for Windows' installed! VSCode and Git could be a lot more helpful about this!

video_title: GitHub Copilot X 설명 | 큰 진전...
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
A few days ago, GitHub released news of an upgrade to GitHub Copilot called GitHub Copilot X. With a new chat feature, PR ecosystem AI, CLI support, Voice coding, and integration with maintainer-written documentation, this is going to be a game-changer. 

With all the talk of ChatGPT and GPT-4, I feel we're missing out on the specific focus and cutting-edge innovation by Microsoft and its Copilot software. 

In this video, I want to walk you through the following:

1. How GitHub Copilot is making developers everywhere happy and
2. What is GitHub Copilot X and what features is it bringing to the table. 

We'll look at all the new features in detail with examples. 

There isn't a set GitHub Copilot X release date yet nor a pricing announcement. GitHub Copilot pricing is $10/mo for individuals and for businesses $19 per user per month. GitHub Copilot X requires an active GitHub Copilot license to get on the waitlist.

Let's discuss in the comments!

video_title: ContinueDev + CodeQwen: 이 로컬 및 오픈소스 대안으로 Github의 Copilot에 대한 비용 지불을 중단하세요
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this video, I'll be telling you about a new local and free github copilot alternative called ContinueDev. I'll also tell you how you can stop paying for Github's Copilot Coding Assistant with this FREE, LOCAL & Opensource coding assistant called ContinueDev. We'll be combining this VS Code & NeoVim extension with CodeQwen. This alternative can be used with any opensource LLM, OpenAI models or Claude models such as GPT-4O, Claude-3, CodeQwen, Mixtral 8x22b, Mixtral 8x7b, GPT-4, Grok-1.5 & Gemini Code Assist.

[Key Takeaways]
🔍 Discover AI-Powered Coding: Learn how to break free from costly tools like GitHub Copilot and explore open-source alternatives like CodeQwen and ContinueDev.

💡 Leverage EvalPlus Leaderboard: Find the best coding models using the EvalPlus Leaderboard, a benchmark that rigorously evaluates AI coders.

🚀 Use CodeQwen-1.5: Uncover the power of CodeQwen-1.5, a top-performing open-source model that supports 92 coding languages and runs efficiently on low resources.

🛠️ Integrate with ContinueDev: Enhance your coding experience with ContinueDev, a powerful extension offering autocompletion, chat, and code highlighting for seamless AI integration.

🌐 Set Up Ollama for Local AI: Learn how to use Ollama to serve your AI models locally and securely, ensuring your sensitive code remains private.

⚡ Optimize with Groq API: Discover how to use Groq, a fast model inference API, to harness the power of AI coding without needing a GPU.

📈 Maximize Productivity: See how combining CodeQwen, ContinueDev, and Ollama boosts your productivity, making coding faster, more efficient, and secure.

🔧 Step-by-Step Setup Guide: Follow our detailed setup instructions to get started with CodeQwen, ContinueDev, and Ollama quickly and easily.

video_title: IntelliJ IDEA를 활용한 GitHub Copilot 튜토리얼
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
#githubcopilot  #javatutorial #java #ai #intellijidea

GitHub source code: https://github.com/CraftOfProgramming...

In this tutorial, we demonstrate how to install and use the GitHub Copilot plugin within IntelliJ IDEA. The video guides you through the installation process, resolving potential keyboard shortcut conflicts, and showcases how GitHub Copilot assists in coding tasks, such as implementing methods and validating input parameters. We also delve into generating reservation classes and integrating JUnit5 for testing purposes, providing practical examples of how Copilot can streamline your workflow.

00:27 Handling Keyboard Shortcuts and Suggestions
00:56 Integrating GitHub Copilot with IDE

02:16 Handling Reservation Capacity
02:33 Optimizing Reservation Algorithm
03:13 JUnit5 Parameterized Tests
03:44 Fixing Parameterized Test Errors
03:58 Improving Java Documentation with Better Prompts

video_title: Copilot X가 출시되었습니다. VS Code에서 직접 사용해 보았습니다.
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Are you curious about the next generation of AI tools for code generation? Introducing Copilot X, an advanced enhancement to the well-regarded GitHub Copilot. This video offers a detailed exploration of the capabilities and use cases of Copilot X and its key component, Copilot Chat.
As an evolved iteration of GitHub Copilot, Copilot X brings new potential for generating larger portions of code, refactoring classes and methods, and providing coverage with unit tests. It demonstrates how AI is increasingly shaping the landscape of programming and code development.
Witness firsthand how Copilot X interacts seamlessly with Visual Studio Code and learn about its context-aware conversation feature, a remarkable tool that lets you refine requirements until you reach an acceptable portion of generated code.
Please note that, despite the impressive capabilities of Copilot X and Copilot Chat, they do not replace the vital role of a developer in writing code. Rather, they serve as powerful allies, aiding in efficiency and accuracy.
Join me in this video to discover how Copilot X and Copilot Chat can contribute to your programming toolkit. Explore their unique features and learn how to integrate them into your development process.

comment: Thanks, I'm on the waiting list already, just limping along with current Co-pilot right now in VS2022.   I'm undecided whether its more helpful to me than the built in intellisense which is very good.   Where before I would type a few characters and tab to accept the simpler but usually on point suggestion from intellisense, I now see larger chunks of code which is often not what I want.  Hence I have to keep typing.   On average I suspect I can write the code I want faster with intellisense than I can by occasionally accepting Co-pilot's larger offerings.
