video_title: High-income AI business ideas for 2025 (no coding, no budget)
author: @theaiworkshopp
comment:
Marina, this video is absolutely brilliant! Your timing couldn't be better - I've been stuck in analysis paralysis thinking I need to learn coding or raise tons of capital to build something meaningful. But you just proved that the barrier to entry has never been lower and the opportunity has never been bigger.

That story about your friend's startup growing 260% in one day is insane! And I love how you're not just throwing around theoretical ideas - you're actually building these content factories yourself and sharing real examples like Garfield AI and Logistify AI. The fact that you're hiring people with no experience because everything changes so fast really hit home.

Your advice to solve your own problem first is gold. I've been overthinking market analysis when I should just focus on what's frustrating me daily. The AI agents for small businesses idea especially resonates because I see so many local businesses struggling with basic automation.

Already bookmarked all the tools you mentioned - Lovable, Replit, and Poppy AI look incredible. This video didn't just give me business ideas, it completely shifted my mindset about what's possible right now. Thank you for always keeping it real about the Silicon Valley perspective while making it accessible to the rest of us!

video_title: I spent a day researching about the 2025-26 coding job market.
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
이번 에피소드에서는 기술 일자리 시장의 현재 상황(2025~2026년)을 심층적으로 살펴보고, 기업이 채용을 줄이는 이유, AI가 생산성에 대한 기대치를 어떻게 변화시켰는지, 그리고 젊은 엔지니어들이 성공하기 위해 채택해야 할 전략은 무엇인지 알아봅니다.

타임스탬프:
00:00 – 소개(2025년 일자리 시장 현황)
00:30 – 보존 모드에 있는 창업자 – 채용 속도 저하 및 면접 주기 연장
01:32 – AI 생산성 변화 – 채용 감소, 엔지니어에 대한 기대치 상승
03:00 – 마지막 10% 문제 – AI는 90% 속도 향상, 하지만 마무리 작업에는 여전히 사람이 필요
04:01 – 비현실적인 기대 – AI 과대평가, 단기 채용 추세
04:30 – 추천 = 불공정한 이점 – 네트워크가 300건 이상의 무작위 지원자를 이겼다
06:29 – 첫 번째 제안을 빠르게 받기 – "완벽한" 고소득 일자리를 기다리지 마세요
08:37 – 처음부터 준비하세요 – 스타트업 및 원격 근무에 대한 새로운 기대치 상승
10:07 – 클린 코드 및 기본 원칙 사고 – LeetCode의 힘든 작업만으로는 충분하지 않은 이유
12:10 – 폭 vs. 깊이 – 두 가지 엔지니어링 인도 생태계에서 두각을 나타내는 방법
14:00 – 결론 및 최종 조언

author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Ooooft, this one has been in the pipe for a while now but finally got around to finishing the edit. Seriously interesting experiment, I'm wondering if I should do some livestreams and we can tweak and backtest params live to see what works? 🤷🏽‍♂️

Probably will get back to reinforcement learning for ML and some deep visualisation stuff I've been wanting to get my hands on, alas I digress. In this, you're going to learn; 
1. How to hook up a bot to Kraken 
2. How to setup a LLM to help make trading decisions (see performance for yourself don't at me with "you should've used {insert fav llm here} llm" 😅
3. How to refactor all the code you just wrote and use finbert. 

All the code, logs and stuff is available via GitHub as always: https://github.com/nicknochnack/LLMAg...

author: @edzaizvobwo
comment: AI has an overfitting problem that's why it doesn't generalise. It is overfitted for the training data. That's why these models do well during testing and it doesn't translate into great performance in the real world.

video_title: Is there an AI coding bubble? Plus Meta’s new SlopTok product and more | E2184
author: @verebgyorgy9307
comment: I think you are both on the two ends of the distribution, most people don't have many good and cheap enough options to chane from large providers such as google. Also most people simply avoid the effort that swiching would mean. Meanwhile I don't know of anybody who would click on ads either. For example I just accept that ads are 'kind of' the price for free sources of information but I would never click on them without a good reason. Maybe 4 times a year i do click, since that is how often I truly need something. So four times a month sounds on a single platform sounds  overly optimistic. Do you know about some statistical data that supports that?

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @joefreeman3772
comment: its easier for companies to tell investors that the  layoffs are due to 'AI Effeciency Measures'  than it is to say "Business is slow" which is really the case.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @alanthomasgramont
comment: Something else that is not discussed is that junior devs who use AI don't learn senior skills. So when all us old senior devs retire who is going to be the next wave of senior devs? If the expectation is that junior devs are going to vibe code for 5 years and then suddenly be able to fix the code they almost mindlessly produced for 5 years, I think there is going to be a huge wakeup call.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @kh884488
comment: I work in technology consulting and I'm so tired with all the overwhelming AI hype these days. I wish I could simply hibernate until this period of mania passes. It is an important technology and will be with us going forward, but its benefits are definitely oversold by the hype factory these days.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @Viroscope
comment: Ai for coding is for support of not replacement of coders right now

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @cheese-power
comment: What? I still have to use my brain? This is outrageous

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @machine1st
comment: For a seasoned programmer with years of experience, AI tools are an incredible asset. The level of code documentation they provide is simply outstanding. However, if you ask me to rely entirely on an AI agent to build a program just by giving prompts, my answer would be a firm no. Instead, I see AI as a coding buddy; a collaborative partner to discuss ideas, exchange code snippets, and refine logic. Once the code is solid, I can then request clean, well-structured documentation for the newly built codebase.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @Mxyzptlk30
comment: These execs think they'll save money by simply forcing everyone to vibe code is similar to their thinking that we'll just ship all this work to India without a clear plan.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @jonathanrutledge3469
comment: IT's not AI taking our jobs it's offshoring basically the same thing that happened with manufacturing.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @ghoser1986
comment: Andrej Karpathy’s recent Y combinator talk explains it well. AI can make suggestions and help you plan, but you need a human to review. This applies at junior and senior levels.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @gQman1057
comment: I’m a senior developer and using ai doing pretty complex coding, and once in about maybe 100 different tasks I got code that worked without modifications.  Half of the time there is a lot of garbage for example, calls to methods that don’t exist.  After my first attempt it became completely obvious that the thing does not understand anything. It’s just regurgitating what it calculates is an answer, and when prompted to correct itself it often barfs even worse code.  It all hype. LLMs are never going to reach general intelligence.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @vandalphilosopher1971
comment: An strategic problem with this approach is that most junior programmers are just going to copy and paste whatever the AI spits out and are not going to really learn the nuances and intricacies required to develop complex systems, so when the most seasoned programmers retire there will be a huge hole in their level of expertise that will be very difficult to fill.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @larsf.4756
comment: This mirrors what we see at my company. Junior developers see a productivity gain, senior developers see little to no gains. However, depending on how many senior to junior developers the company has, there may still be a gain. The current AI models are also not very strong in code maintenance. However, this should also be balanced against the cost of AI, which is resource intensive. This refers to what is commonly called "vibe coding" with the AI suggesting code changes during development. Agentic AI is still a different story.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @richystocles
comment: Id love to see the stick overflow stats for the Last 2 years

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @savm-7252i
comment: We got rid of debugging and accelerated development years ago with test-driven development. To go back to tons of debugging on a tool is a regression

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @bonecircuit
comment: Your cognitive glass roof is the most important barrier. The way you approach the problem with exposition is the Achilles heel to your tool usage.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @williamseipp9691
comment:
What Deirdre is saying is absolutely my experience.

If I want to make something simple then yeah an AI tool can help me rough draft that in minutes. I've had it make changes to my window manager, write a Python script that enabled speech to text to run locally ( vosk ), and help me implement features in bash shell that I'm used to in fish.

But for challenging tasks that require 'taste' and intelligent reasoning about tradeoffs it just falls short. Ive been reviewing a LOT of vibe coding and it's a mixed bag: when it's good it's good and when it's bad it's laughably bad.

AI models work best when you are pedantic and precise; you dont give it room to hallucinate and your prompts have to ne very ordered to specify the kind of edge cases you eant to account for.

But at that point of specificity why not just use the language itself to articulate ideas?

It goes back to what a senior engineer told me about Eclipse and UML diagrams 'back in the day': the idea was to leverage the explicit nature of Java and the detail in UML class diagrams so that you could use it to generate code.

But LOL at that point you've just created another DSL / abstraction layer! Could've just done it in the original context.

So it's not all sunshine and rainbows. I'm sure it will improve and I'm not going to stop vibe coding and trying to push it to it's limits but you gotta call it like it is.

and to use the whole 'the guy using AI will take your job' angle: yeah, I guess but it's that true of all tools?

If you are using a handsaw to cut 2x4s on a job site you will get laughed at; use a circular saw or miter saw.

Why use a stapler when you can use a hammer stapler. A framing hammer is still needed at times but by and large you should be using a nail gun. Know your tools and use the right tool for the job and you'll be effective versus the person who refuses to adapt.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @mychaljohnston3522
comment: Simple well-scoped tasks are rare and not typically very valuable. The meat and potatoes of engineering is the vaguely defined, unscoped request from customers or management that require significant work and analysis to scope and to connect real world requirements with technical details.

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @daryl4225
comment: instead of babysitting one person, you are now babysitting 1.5 entities. productivity!

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @ItsKettenhofen
comment: Rethinking AI coding is essential. It's not just about faster code, but also about reimagining the collaborative possibilities between humans and machines. Great insights!

video_title: Rethinking the AI coding payoff
author: @IIIxwaveIII
comment: cant agree more. using gpt,claude,etc slows many seniors down... hours of debugging and roundtrips. a simple google , forums, chats, are at this point more helpful for senior devs

video_title: 코딩할 줄 몰라도 다 된다... AI가 연 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 부상, 진짜 개발자는 없어지나?
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
인공지능 코딩 보조 기술인 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 도구의 부상으로 소프트웨어 개발 방식이 근본적으로 변화하고 있습니다. 테슬라와 OpenAI에서 활동한 안드레이 카파시가 제시한 바이브 코딩은 AI에게 자연어로 지시하여 프로그램을 만드는 새로운 코딩 방식입니다. 이는 GPT-4, LLaMA 같은 초거대 언어 모델이 방대한 데이터로 학습되어 가능해졌습니다. 대표적인 AI 코딩 도구인 Cursor AI나 GitHub Copilot은 코드 생성 및 수정, 버그 해결 보조 등을 통해 개발 생산성을 크게 높이고 있습니다. AI가 코딩 작업 속도를 평균 55%까지 빠르게 하지만, 개발자는 AI가 생성한 코드를 검토하고 통합하는 데 더 많은 시간을 할애하기도 합니다. 한편, 로우코드/노코드 플랫폼은 적은 코드 또는 코드 작성 없이도 애플리케이션 제작을 가능하게 하여 개발의 민주화를 목표로 합니다. 이는 개발 인력 부족과 소프트웨어 수요 증가 문제를 해결하고, 현업과 개발자 간 소통을 원활하게 하는 대안으로 주목받고 있습니다. 가트너에 따르면 글로벌 로우코드/노코드 시장은 고속 성장 중이며, Microsoft Power Platform과 같은 플랫폼은 이미 수천만 명의 사용자를 확보했습니다. 흥미롭게도 로우코드 툴의 주요 사용자는 오히려 전문 개발자들이며, 비개발자의 활용도 AI 통합으로 점차 쉬워지고 있습니다. 이러한 변화는 개발자의 역할을 단순 코딩에서 벗어나 설계, 관리, AI와의 협업 중심으로 변화시킬 것입니다. 개발자는 AI의 산출물을 검토하고 조정하는 디렉터나 품질관리자 역할을 수행하며, 기본기 강화와 함께 인간 고유의 문제 해결 및 설계 역량이 더욱 중요해집니다. 결국 AI 코딩 보조와 로우코드/노코드 도구를 능동적으로 받아들이고 자신의 역량을 재정비하는 개발자가 이 변화의 시대에 가치 있는 인재로 남을 것입니다.

Written by Error
Edited by 이지호

video_title: 코딩할 줄 몰라도 다 된다... AI가 연 '바이브 코딩'과 로우코드/노코드 부상, 진짜 개발자는 없어지나?
author: @sjohn9412
comment:
13년차 개발자 현 ai 개발자.
진짜 맞다이 까면 내가 더 잘할 수 있을거 같다가도, 쓰다보니까 점점 떠남기는 영역이 많고
이제 코드를 읽는게 슬슬 귀찮아짐. 디버깅은 이제 거의 ai 전담임...
하나씩 내 영역을 넘기는데 점점 잘해진다 얘가..
6개월에 한번씩 정말 깜짝깜짝 놀람.. 왜냐? 분명히 6개월전엔 이거 못했거든..
근데 더 놀라운건 이제 정말 간단한 코드도 잘 기억이 안난다.. 하도 떠넘겼더니.
마치 네비없던 시절 서울길 다 외우다가 네비 생기고 길못찾거나
후방감지기 없을때 조수석에 손얹고 폭풍후진 하다가. 이제는 띠띠띠 없으면 거리도 못재게 된것처럼.
1년안에 바이브코딩을 넘어 노코딩 세계로 갈거 같다.

author: @sunghoonjung9570
comment: 저같은 경우는 IT 분야 엔지니어는 아니고 기계공학분야 구조 설계엔지니어인데 아무래도 설계엔지니어는 엑셀이나 코딩을 통해서 각종 설계를 위한 부품의 위치와 크기에 대한 계산을 하는게 핵심이죠. 그런데 이전에는 어떻게 하면 계산을 효율적으로 자동으로 하는지에 대한 대략적인 개념은 머리속에 있는데 막상 코딩을 할줄 몰라서 막히는게 정말로 많았습니다. 그런데 이걸 다 챗지피티나 제미나이에게 단계적으로 구체적인 설명을 하면 제가 필요한 수준에선 웬만한게 다 결과로 나오더군요. 실로 놀라운 수준입니다. 조만간에 여기서 더 발전하면 일반 인공지능이 나올지도 모르는데 아무튼 최근 몇년사이에 인공지능으로 인해서 일하는 방식이 완전히 달라졌습니다.

video_title: 코딩없이 가능한 AI 에이전트! 초보자용 n8n 실전 튜토리얼
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
코딩 없이도 나만의 AI 에이전트를 만들 수 있다면? 
이번 영상에서는 무료로 활용할 수 있는 자동화 툴 n8n을 활용해, 일정 관리를 도와주는 AI 개인비서를 직접 만들어 보았습니다. 
n8n을 처음 사용해보는 분들도 따라하실 수 있도록, AI Agent의 각 요소에 대한 설명은 물론 구글 서비스 인증, 시스템 프롬프트까지 상세히 설명하였는데요. 

코딩없이 Ai Agent를 만들어서 활용해보고 싶으신 분이라면, 이번 영상 참고하셔서 본인만의 생산성을 높여주는 AI Agent를 만들어보시기 바랍니다. 

🧠 여러분은 어떤 AI 에이전트를 만들고 싶으신가요? 댓글로 공유해 주세요 :)

video_title: 다가올 AI 에이전트의 시대, 애플, 쿠팡, 아마존, 딥시크까지 총 정리 | AI 에이전트 2부 | 조코딩의 리코딩AI
author: @around_god
comment: 이게 현실이 된다면 앞으로 개인 사생활을 폰에 담아두면 안되겠네요. 오픈 ai들이 앨범 및 메모장 등 프라이빗한 공간까지 다 들어와서 훔쳐볼 수 있으니까요.

video_title: 다가올 AI 에이전트의 시대, 애플, 쿠팡, 아마존, 딥시크까지 총 정리 | AI 에이전트 2부 | 조코딩의 리코딩AI
author: @imaginaryworldin
comment: 사람들이 쇼핑을 하고 시간을 쓰는 이유는 AI가 순식간에 물건을 찾아주는 쇼핑 습관과는 갭이 있다고 생각합니다. 사려는 물건 자체도 중요하지만, 내가 원하는 물건을 여기 저기 찾아가는 활동과 노력, 비교하고 분석하고 고민하는 과정 자체를 즐기는 것이 쇼핑 활동의 중요한 포인트라는 거죠. 이게 AI 때문에 다 뒤집어지지는 않을겁니다. AI가 바로 물건을 찾아 구매까지 해주면, 어릴때 엄마가 물건을 골라 사주는 것과 AI가 골라주는 것과 무슨 차이가 있겠어요.  쇼핑 과정을 줄여주는 것이 필요하면 AI를 활용하면 되겠죠. 쇼핑의 즐거움을 AI에게 뺏기기 싫은 겁니다. 그래서 AI 전문가의 예측이 미래 그 자체가 될 수 없는 겁니다.

video_title: AI검색, AI에이전트의 시대 ‘마케팅 패러다임’은 어떻게 바뀔까? (강정수 박사)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
“AI검색으로의 재편은 마케팅의 근본적인 패러다임 전환입니다. 나아가 메타와 아마존, 구글의 AI에이전트는 타켓별 상세페이지 제작은 물론 퍼포먼스 마케팅과 브랜드 마케팅을 대행하고 있습니다. 마케팅 지형이 완전히 바뀌는 것이죠.”  

AI검색, AI에이전트는 마케팅의 패러다임을 어떻게 바꾸고 있을까요? 대기업은 어떻게 대응해야 하고, 자원이 부족했던 중소기업과 1인기업은 어떻게 이 기회를 활용해야 할까요? 강정수 박사의 이야기를 들어보시죠.

author: @junhojuno
comment:
안녕하세요, 좋은 영상 감사합니다.
AI agent 개발에 있어서 tool을 만들어 주는 기준이 궁금한데요, openai에서 제공하는 llm api의 경우 곱하기, 더하기 정도는 tool을 만들지 않아도 잘 응답을 주는걸 확인했습니다.
tool은 llm이 똑똑해질수록 제공하지 않아도 되는건가요? llm이 충분히 똑똑하지 못해 적절한 응답을 주지 못할경우 tool을 만들어 사용할 수 있도록 지정해주는것이 올바른 방향인지 궁금합니다.

video_title: 웹 브라우저 장악하면 AI에이전트 장악한다
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
검색 부문의 강제 분할 방안을 놓고 미 법무부와 구글이 줄다리기를 하고 있습니다. 구글 검색과 크롬 브라우저 분리는 절대 안 된다는 구글, 크롬 브라우저를 팔고 구글 검색의 기본 설정을 없애라는 법무부. 이 사이에서 오픈AI와 퍼플렉시티는 크롬 브라우저에 눈독을 들이고 있습니다. 브라우저가 기존 검색 뿐 아니라 AI 검색,  AI 에이전트 시대의 새로운 전장이 되고 있습니다.

video_title: 웹 브라우저 장악하면 AI에이전트 장악한다
author: @vagrant_thomas
comment:
개인적으로 크롬 가격 250억달러는 매우 헐값이라고 생각한다.
만약 누군가 250억에 크롬을 인수한다면 그는 일년 후 250억달러를 전부 회수하는데 무리가 없을 것이다.
그만큼 크롬의 가치는 크다는 의미다.
그러므로 크롬은 최소 1천억달러를 주더라도 절대 비싼 것이 아니라고 할 수 있다.
단, 수년 내 크롬의 지위가 커다란 위협을 받지 않는다는 전제하데 말이다.

author: @SiddharthSingh8A
comment: Love how Cal compares Claude Code to that coworker who just lives in the terminal, makes it all way more relatable for folks who aren’t super GUI-dependent—I mostly track my LLM stuff in aiCarma, but this talk got me considering more hands-on terminal work again.

video_title: Claude Code best practices | Code w/ Claude
author: @jediminded
comment: Claude code has armed thinkers with an unrivalled execution tool

video_title: Claude Code best practices | Code w/ Claude
author: @TheQuinnB
comment: Quiet in the Back! I'm trying to listen to the Oracle

video_title: Claude Code best practices | Code w/ Claude
author: @Gulrez-
comment:
I am a doctor, nothing to do with coding/ computer programming/ AI. Picked up an interest in n8n, automation, AI driven workflows and finally Claude Code (1 week quite intense experience). I am shocked, I know exactly what Cal is talking about, and the question about sub agents - the answer is preservation of context in master and all .MD files as a condition from the outset, and when developing complex workflows to keep hammering claude code to auto update.
It helps to name sub agents, literally, so much easier to call them up, and to build this in to .md files. 
So, on my login - I am greeted by sonnet 4 (Little Sister), Sergeant Major (Master Orchestrator), Chloe, Daisy, Dixy and Dawn all subagents, linked but distinct and evolving roles. Auto improvement and best practice also baked in.

Down side is I hit my limit so easily now as the project evolves. I am learning and loving this - still with zero developer or computing background.

The world is changing……!

video_title: Anthropic 공동 창립자: Claude Code 구축, GPT-3 및 LLM 시스템 설계에서 얻은 교훈
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
톰 브라운은 OpenAI에서 GPT-3 개발에 참여한 후 Anthropic을 공동 창립했습니다. 독학으로 엔지니어가 된 그는 선형대수학에서 B-를 받았지만, AI 확장성 혁신을 이끄는 핵심 인물 중 한 명으로 성장했습니다. 그리고 그의 노력은 결실을 맺고 있습니다.

오늘날 Anthropic의 클로드는 개발자들이 가장 선호하는 인물이며, 그의 팀은 그가 "인류 역사상 가장 큰 규모의 인프라 구축"이라고 부르는 프로젝트를 감독하고 있습니다. The Lightcone의 이번 에피소드에서 그는 YC 창업자에서 AI 연구자로의 파격적인 여정, 모든 것을 바꾼 확장성 법칙의 발견, 그리고 오늘날 AI 분야에 뛰어드는 젊은 엔지니어들에게 주는 조언에 대해 이야기합니다.

Y Combinator 지원: https://www.ycombinator.com/apply
스타트업 취업: https://www.ycombinator.com/jobs

챕터:

author: @dddavet9652
comment: Very impressive talk. As a software engineer I 100% agree that the perspective of software engineering getting jobs will change. Previously almost all college students strived to get a lucrative job with companies like FAANG but the way I see it is that it won't necessarily be the same but risk takers will stand out the most. video_title: 클로드 엔지니어는 정말 미쳤어요... 클로드 코드 워크플로를 업그레이드하세요
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
실제 AI 엔지니어링을 지원하는 Claude Code 워크플로를 활용하세요. 이 Claude Code 튜토리얼은 Claude Code 사용법, 워크플로 설정, 그리고 사용자 지정 설정의 마스터 방법을 정확하게 보여줍니다. 개발자와 Vibe Coder 모두를 위한 최고의 Claude Code 설정 가이드입니다.

링크: 
Docs.md: http://bit.ly/4nEz8EZ

이 심층적인 Claude Code 가이드에서는 Super Claude가 어떻게 Anthropic Claude Code를 진정한 AI 코딩의 동반자로 만들어 주는지 살펴봅니다. Context-7 및 Sequential MCP와 같은 Claude Code MCP 통합부터 고급 Claude Code 명령, 후크, 플래그까지, 이 가이드는 단순한 Claude 코드 리뷰 그 이상입니다. Claude Code와 Cursor가 실제 개발 워크플로에서 어떻게 활용되는지, 그리고 Claude 4 Opus와 적절한 설정 파일을 함께 사용하면 완전히 새로운 수준의 Vibe 코딩이 어떻게 구현되는지 확인할 수 있습니다.

AI에 심도 있게 접근하든 프롬프트 엔지니어링을 이제 막 시작하든, 이 클로드 코드 튜토리얼은 설정부터 실행까지 모든 것을 다룹니다. 여러 기기에서 클로드를 브라우저에 연결하는 방법, 커서 AI와 클로드가 docs.md와 claude.md를 사용하여 워크플로를 자동화하는 방법까지 다룹니다.

게다가, Gemini CLI, ChatGPT, SEO 지원 워크플로, 그리고 클로드와 커서 같은 도구를 기반으로 하는 AI 에이전트가 코딩을 그 어느 때보다 쉽게 만드는 방법에 대한 해설도 제공합니다.

클로드 코드를 효과적으로 사용하는 방법을 알고 싶거나 AI 에이전트 워크플로에서 커서와 클로드를 비교하고 싶다면, 바로 이 가이드가 정답입니다.

comment: Here's something  I have found particularly useful if you want to use something like Claude in a browser on your phone or similar from anywhere. Set up a tailscale network. For personal set up its free, you can connect 100 devices. I have my Linux dev servers, phones and laptops all on it, and you can set it up no fuss. in a few minutes, you are away. I used this set up for code-server which is browser based vscode. I promise you its worth the 10 minutes setting it up, not just for this but also your general device security. IF you need help with it, most LLM's are excellent at giving guidance on this topic.

video_title: Anthropic’s NEW Claude Code Review Agent (Full Open Source Workflow)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
I'm on a mission to document my journey of becoming an AI-native founder, sharing every powerful workflow and hard-won insight along the way.

You're welcome to join my newsletter (https://patrickellis.beehiiv.com/subs...) or subscribe here, if you're a founder or software engineer looking to build faster and smarter with AI Agents like Claude Code, Codex, Cursor, Gemini, ChatGPT, n8n, image/video gen, and other AI workflows.

The speech-to-text voice tool I use is called superwhisper. If you check it out via my affiliate link, it helps support the channel (I may earn a small commission): https://superwhisper.com/?via=patrick

Anthropic's Claude Code team just open-sourced the tooling they use to replace manual code reviews with AI agents. If you're drowning in AI-generated code, this agentic review system is the key to unlocking massive velocity while ensuring your code is secure and follows best practices.

This video is a step-by-step guide to implementing Anthropic's playbook. I break down their agentic review system, showing you how to use Slash Commands, custom Subagents, and fully automated GitHub Action runners to handle code and security audits. I'll also cover the high-level mental frameworks you need to build powerful, custom AI workflows for your own team.

Core Sections & Timestamps:
00:00 - The Problem: AI Code Review is the New Bottleneck
00:44 - How Anthropic Replaced Human Reviewers with AI Agents
02:39 - Part 1: The Anthropic Code Review Lifecycle
06:02 - Part 2: The Agentic Loop (Inner vs. Outer)
07:19 - Part 3: The Agent Orchestration Layer
09:37 - Part 4: High Leverage Mental Frameworks
14:27 - Part 5: Inner Loop Code / Security Review Workflow & Demo
16:11 - Demo: The New /security-review Command
16:48 - Part 6: Deep Dive on Anthropic’s Open Sourced Repos
20:16 - Part 7: How to Create Any Custom Subagent or Slash Command
23:54 - Part 8: Outer Loop Code / Security Review Workflow & Demo
25:39 - Live Demo: Automated PR Review with GitHub Actions
27:00 - Part 9: Best Open Source Agent/Command Templates
29:02 - Conclusion & Next Steps

You can find my Subagent, Slash Command, and GitHub Action config files (showcased in the video) here: https://github.com/OneRedOak/claude-c...

Claude Code가 지금 가장 주목받고 있습니다. Cursor와 같은 다른 AI 코딩 도구를 사용해 보셨다면 Claude Code가 실제로 더 나은지 궁금하실 겁니다.

이 영상에서는 Claude Code 사용에 대한 두 가지 중요한 질문을 살펴봅니다.

1. 터미널 기반 인터페이스가 더 나은가요? 어떤 상황에서 적합할까요?

video_title: 클로드 코드의 사례
author: @CraigHollabaugh
comment:
I'm 62 and have been coding since 1978  (yes 47 yrs). Saw a claude-code demo a week ago, went home immediately and started playing. In a week, we, me and Claude, crafted an embedded cellular IoT app with a complete AWS data lake backend. Mind boggling is an understatement and Claude solved the bain of software development, documentation. Everything gets updated with every commit. Claude put the fun back in development. 

My next project is an industrial data acquisition system with about 20 interacting components. Couldn't sleep one night, I spent about 2 hours planning this project with claude phone app in bed.  We came up with a project plan, architectural layout and selected redis with Go because of its concurrency model. I know nothing about Go and am wondering if I even need to. We'll see. Thanks for the video.

video_title: Claude Code Is Now on the $20 Pro Plan — Setup & Features (Just Announced!)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Claude Code is now available on Anthropic’s $20 Pro plan, making it more accessible than ever. In this video, I’ll show you how to set it up, walk through the key features and limitations, and compare it to the $100 Max and API plans. Whether you’re new to AI coding or just want a more affordable way to explore Claude Code, this guide will get you started.

Videos:
1. Claude Code Installation Guide: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/cl...
Terminal Command to Run: npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

2. Claude Code $20 Pro Plan vs $100 Max Plan Feature Comparison: https://support.anthropic.com/en/arti...

3. How to optimize token usage in Claude Code:    • How to Optimize Token Usage in Claude Code

author: @maury1329
comment:
Thank you for the video.
For me, this user environment variable was required for Claude Code to work under native Windows:
CLAUDE_CODE_GIT_BASH_PATH=C:\Program Files\Git\git-bash.exe (or wherever else you have GitBash after installing Git)
That was after I had tis error:Error: No suitable shell found. Claude CLI requires a Posix shell environment. Please ensure you have a valid shell installed and the SHELL environment variable set.

author: @Lia__17-k8j
comment:
잘 봤습니다. 그런데 영상에서 보여준 task들은 전부 무언가를 생성하는 작업들이고, 가상의 제품을 이용한 예시라 hallucination 문제가 크게 드러나지 않은 것 같습니다. 하지만 실제 활용에서는 어느 정도의 정확도로 조사하고 자료를 작성할 수 있는지가 핵심일 것 같습니다.
어차피 기존 Gemini 모델을 기반으로 한다면, 환각 발생 수준도 기존 모델과 유사할 것 같기는 한데.. 원래라면 딥리서치 결과를 사람이 검토한 뒤 다음 단계(이미지·영상 생성)로 넘어가는 과정에서 잘못된 정보를 걸러낼 수 있었을텐데, 이번 방식은 그런 검증 절차가 없다보니 초기에는 작은 환각이었던 것이 최종 결과물에서는 큰 오류로 확대될 가능성도 있어보이네요. 
hallucination이 생겨서 결과가 이상해지면 전체 시나리오를 다시 돌려야할텐데 사용량이 어느정도까지 될지도 궁금합니다.

author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
_________IoT Based Water Quality Monitoring system__________




Abstract :-

This project involves the development of a comprehensive water quality monitoring system based on the ESP32 microcontroller and the Adafruit platform. The system is designed to measure key water quality parameters, including Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), temperature, pH, and turbidity. The ESP32 processes data from various sensors that monitor these parameters, and the information is transmitted to the Adafruit platform for real-time visualization and analysis. This integration allows users to access detailed insights into water quality from any location, facilitating timely interventions and ensuring safe and clean water management. The system enhances environmental monitoring, supports water treatment processes, and provides valuable data for maintaining optimal water quality standards.

video_title: 2024년 인기 있는 DevOps 모니터링 도구
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Monitoring Tools in DevOps: In this DevOps video we look at all the popular and most used Monitoring Tools in DevOps including Prometheus, Nagios, Grafana and more.
Monitoring in DevOps is very important to make sure systems, infrastructures, and services are up and if there are any issues, we should be notified at real time.

DevOps Engineer should have experience and knowledge of Different Devops monitoring tools that are used and this video will help you learn all the different monitoring tools, with their features and use cases.

✨ Register for KodeKloud Free week: http://kode.wiki/44PGk6r

Connect with me on LinkedIn:   / nasiullha-chaudhari  

Why DevOps Engineers Should Learn Monitoring: 
Integration with DevOps Practices
Effective Incident Management
Resource Optimization
Automated Scaling
Data-Driven Decision Making
Enhanced Collaboration within Teams
#monitoring #devops

Timestamps - 
Importance of Monitoring in DevOps 0:00
Different monitoring types. 0:32
What is Server monitoring 0:56
What is Network monitoring. 01:29
What is Cost Monitoring. 01:55
Popular Monitoring tools in DevOps.  02:38
Prometheus Tool. 02:48
Grafana monitoring Tool. 05:05
Nagios Monitoring Tool 05:44
ELK Stack Monitoring 06:20
New Relic Monitoring Tool. 07:29
Dynatrace Monitoring Tool 08:17
Splunk Monitoring Tool. 09:10
AppDynamics monitoring Tool. 09:50

Some Popular DevOps Monitoring tools are:
1. Prometheus: An open-source monitoring and alerting system designed for reliability and scalability.
2. Grafana: A platform for visualizing and analyzing monitoring data, often used alongside Prometheus.
3. ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana): A stack of tools used for log analysis, data processing, and visualization.
4. Splunk: A comprehensive platform for searching, monitoring, and analyzing machine-generated data, including logs and metrics.
5. Datadog: A cloud-based monitoring and analytics platform with a wide range of integrations for cloud, on-premises, and hybrid environments.
6. New Relic: A tool focused on application performance monitoring (APM), providing insights into application behavior and user experience.
7. Nagios: An open-source monitoring system that provides real-time visibility into IT infrastructure, services, and network resources, with customizable alerting.
8. AppDynamics: A performance monitoring and application intelligence platform that helps organizations gain insights into their applications and user experiences.
9. Dynatrace: An AI-powered application performance monitoring solution that offers end-to-end visibility into application performance and user experiences, with automatic problem detection and root cause analysis.

By the end of the video, you will have clear understanding of how monitoring is used in DevOps, Different monitoring types, also popular monitoring tools that are used by many companies and also asked in interviews.

VPS 관리는, 특히 탄탄한 VPS 모니터링 루틴을 통해, 부담스러울 필요가 없습니다. 이 튜토리얼에서는 Hostinger의 AI 비서 Kodee를 활용하여 매일 서버를 원활하게 운영하는 방법을 보여줍니다. VPS 관리 초보자든 숙련된 사용자든, 이 루틴은 명확한 단계와 Kodee의 사용자 친화적인 가이드를 통해 프로세스를 간소화합니다. 안정성을 위해 먼저 서버의 가동 시간과 부하를 확인한 다음, 리소스 사용량을 면밀히 파악하여 성능 문제를 조기에 발견하세요. Kodee를 사용하면 간편하게 "실행 중인 프로세스 개요를 알려주세요"라고 요청하기만 하면 CPU나 메모리를 차지하는 부분을 확인할 수 있습니다. 그런 다음 로그를 검토하여 오류가 있는지 확인하고 네트워크 활동을 모니터링하여 서버가 온라인 상태이며 접근 가능한지 확인합니다. 마지막으로 간단한 보안 검사를 통해 무단 로그인을 감지합니다. 각 단계에는 Kodee의 출력 결과와 정확한 명령이 제공되므로 언제든지 재현할 수 있습니다. 이 VPS 모니터링 루틴은 웹사이트 소유자, 개발자 또는 Hostinger VPS에서 호스팅하는 모든 사람에게 적합합니다. Hostinger의 안정적인 플랜(설명 상단 링크 참조)과 함께 사용하고 VPS10 코드를 사용하면 10% 할인 혜택을 받을 수 있습니다. 지금 바로 시청하고 따라 하며 자신 있게 서버를 관리하세요!

video_title: LLM 에이전트를 사용하여 SQL 및 테이블 형식 데이터베이스와 채팅하세요(RAG는 사용하지 마세요!)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this video, together we will go through all the steps necessary to design a ChatBot APP to interact with SQL and Tabular Databases using natural language, SQL LLM agents, and GPT 3.5. We will design a Chatbot that can:
1. Chat with SQL DB that we create from SQL files
2. Chat with SQL DB that we create from CSV and XLSX files
3. Chat with  SQL DB that we create by uploading documents while using the chatbot
4. RAG with Tabular data

Moreover, in this video, I will show you why RAG is not a good option for interacting with your databases. The code is available on the Github repository.

🚀 GitHub Repositories:
Advanced Q&A and RAG series:  https://github.com/Farzad-R/Advanced-...
LLM-Zero-To-Hundred Series: https://github.com/Farzad-R/LLM-Zero-...

00:00 Intro
00:41 Roadmap (Q&A vs RAG)
05:59 Resources of the first project
09:35 Project schema walk-through
13:19 Test your GPT and Embedding models (Notebook)
14:44 How to load environment variables (.env file)
17:26 Step 1.1: Create the SQL database from .sqlfile
19:00 Step 1.2: Create the SQL database from CSV and XLSX files
20:22 Step 1.3: Create the VectorDB from CSV and XLSX files
21:25 Step 2: Test your SQL database (Notebook)
22:15 Step 3: Step-by-step guide for Q&A with the SQL database created from SQL file (Notebook)
31:15 Step 4: Q&A with the SQL database created from CSV and XLSX files (Notebook)
36:15 Step 5: RAG with SQL databases and Tabular Data (Notebook)
42:34 ChatBot GUI brief backend walk-through
47:00 UI walk-through
48:25 Demo: Q&A with SQL DB created from .sql file
50:36 Demo: Q&A with SQL DB created from CSV and XLSX files
53:03 Demo: RAG with VectorDB created from CSV and XLSX files
54:45 Demo: Q&A with SQL DB created from uploaded CSV and XLSX files
56:55 Keynotes

Langchain SQL Agent: https://python.langchain.com/docs/use...

Frameworks: #langchain , #openai, gradio, SQLite
#chatbot #rag #llm #agent #python #gpt

video_title: Huggingface와 Pytorch를 사용하여 LLM을 미세 조정하여 무엇이든 가르치세요 | 단계별 튜토리얼
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
This in-depth tutorial is about fine-tuning LLMs locally with Huggingface Transformers and Pytorch. We use Meta's new Llama-3.2-1B-Instruct model and teach it to predict paper categories using LORA adapters. Along the way I break down all the major things you must know about fine-tuning, from prompting, creating datasets, generating input-output pairs, loss functions, pytorch optimizers, peft LORA adapters, and ofcourse the sweet feeling when the test accuracy goes up. :) 

Follow on Twitter: https://x.com/neural_avb

Get 25% off on Ninjachat. Access multiple frontier LLMs, image, video, audio generation models all in one place. Use this link: https://ninjachat.ai/?ref=avishek and the code AI25 to get 25% off!

All the notebooks, datasets, and python code used in this video have been uploaded to my Patreon:
  / neuralbreakdownwithavb  

I upload all the code, slides, animations, write-ups etc for all my videos on my Patreon, so go check it out if you find anything interesting.

Videos you might like:
Llama3.2 Multimodal Application -    • Llama 3.2 Vision - How to make a Multimoda...  
Apple Intelligence LLM Breakdown -    • The Machine Learning behind Apple Intellig...  
50 concepts to know NLP:    • 10 years of NLP history explained in 50 co...  
Attention to Transformers playlist:    • Attention to Transformers from zero to her...  

Notes on Hardware and Quantization:

I didn't go over quantization in this video, coz I'm on a Macbook and bitsandbytes don't work outside NVIDIA gpus. :) Hopefully, I'll make a separate video one day about quantization. 

The system I am using is a MacBook Pro M2 16GB ram. If you have nvidia gpus, you could leverage better quantization. For my machine, I was able to train with batch size of 8 in float32… the sequence lengths were around 250 on average for this task.

If I were working on a product, I’d rent cloud gpu servers and fine tune over there on large datasets. For a YT video with an educational intent, I decided to limit the scope to local machines.

video_title: 지식 그래프와 LLM 에이전트를 사용한 테이블형 데이터베이스와의 채팅 및 RAG
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this video, together we will go through all the steps to construct a #knowledgegraph from Tabular Datasets and design a ChatBot APP to interact with the Knowledge Graph using natural language. For this purpose, we will use Knowledge Graph LLM agents and the GPT model. We will design a Chatbot that can:

1. Chat with Graph DB using an improved LLM agent
2. Chat with Graph DB using a simple LLM agent
3. RAG with Graph DB

Moreover, in this video, I will show you the second RAG approach for interacting with Tabular data but this time, using the knowledge graph. The code is available on the Github repository.

🚀 GitHub Repositories:
Advanced Q&A and RAG series:  https://github.com/Farzad-R/Advanced-...
LLM-Zero-To-Hundred Series: https://github.com/Farzad-R/LLM-Zero-...

00:00:00 Intro - (Presentation)
00:00:17 Table of Contents - (Presentation)
00:01:55 Why Knowledge Graph? - (Presentation)
09:35 Project schema walk-through - (Presentation)
00:06:14 LLM Model Matters - (Presentation)
00:07:26 Series schema (RAG vs Q&A) - (Presentation)
00:08:05 Knowledge Graph Fundamentals - (Presentation)
00:10:29 How to Construct Knowledge Graph - (Presentation)
00:14:12 ChatBot Schema walk-through - (Presentation)
00:16:02 Knowledge Graph Agent schema walk-through - (Presentation)
00:18:00 Second RAG approach for tabular data - (Presentation)
00:18:24 Knowledge Graph for Movie Dataset - (Presentation)
00:21:41 Knowledge Graph for Microsoft medical chatbot  - (Presentation)
00:22:52 ChatBot demo
00:23:36 Graph database installation and configuration 
00:32:27 Code structure walk-through
00:33:25 Verify your OpenAI and Neo4j connection
00:34:39 Download the Movide dataset and generate synthetic data
00:37:15 Construct the knowledge graph from the Movie dataset
00:45:50 Creating and populating the Vector Index in Graph Database
00:51:23 Q&A with GraphDB populated with Knowledge Graph of the Tabular Data (designing the simple and improved agent)
01:07:47 RAG with GraphDB
01:13:22 Testing the ChatBot
01:17:10 Microsoft Medical Chatbot walk-through
01:22:52 Ending notes

Frameworks: #langchain , #openai, gradio, #neo4j, 
#chatbot #rag #llm #agent #python #gpt

video_title: LLM 계측 및 평가
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Join the AI Evals Course starting Jan 27, 2026: https://maven.com/parlance-labs/evals...


. This lesson discusses instrumentation and evaluation of LLMs.  Guest speakers Brian Bischof and  Eugene Yan describe how they think about LLM evaluation in industry.  Finally, Shreya Shankar discusses her research on LLM eval systems.

Slides, notes, and additional resources are available here: https://parlance-labs.com/education/f...

This is lesson of 3 of 4 course on applied fine-tuning:

1. When & Why to Fine-Tune:    • When and Why to Fine Tune an LLM  
2. Fine-Tuning w/Axolotl:    • Fine-Tuning with Axolotl  
3. Instrumenting & Evaluating LLMs:     • Instrumenting & Evaluating LLMs  
4. Deploying Fine-Tuned LLMs:    • Deploying Fine-Tuned Models  

00:00 Overview  

02:05 Evaluations: The Core of the Development Cycle  
Frequent evaluations and rapid updates are central to applied AI. Evaluations can range from automated tests to more manual human reviews.

06:07 Walkthrough of a Unit Test  
Dan demonstrates a unit test in Python designed to test a simple LLM pipeline.

08:55 Unit Tests for LLMs  
Hamel explains the necessity of unit tests and their role in automating the validation of outputs.
To create effective unit tests, enumerate all features the AI should cover, define scenarios for each feature, and generate test data. Synthetic data can be created using LLMs to test various scenarios. 

18:56 LLM as a Judge  
To trust an LLM as a judge, iterate its outputs and measure their correlation with a trusted human standard using spreadsheets. Gradually align the LLM with human critiques to build confidence in its judgments.

21:18 Issues with Using LLMs as Judges  
Dan discusses potential issues with relying on LLMs as judges, primarily due to their inconsistency in results.

23:00 Human Evaluations  
Ongoing human review, data examination, and regular updates are necessary to maintain accuracy and prevent overfitting.

24:44 Rapid Evaluations Lead to Faster Iterations  

Using evaluation strategies effectively can help quickly identify and fix issues or failure cases.

26:30 Issues with Human Evaluations  
Human evaluations can be subjective, potentially leading to varying scores for the same output at different times. A/B testing can help mitigate these issues to some extent.

31:20 Analyzing Traces  
A trace is a sequence of events, such as multi-turn conversations or retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) interactions. Analyzing traces (datasets) should be seamless to understand your data effectively.

35:30 Logging Traces  
Several tools, such as Langsmith, can log and view traces. It’s recommended to use off-the-shelf tools to speed up data analysis.

39:15 Langsmith Walkthrough  
Harrison demonstrates Langsmith, a tool for logging and testing LLM applications. Langsmith also supports visualization of traces and offers features like experiment filtering.

43:12 Datasets and Testing on Langsmith  
Langsmith allows various methods to import, filter, and group datasets. Experiments can be set up to assess model performance across these datasets.

51:35 Common Mistakes in Evaluating LLMs  
Bryan provides a brief overview of common pitfalls in LLM evaluation and how to avoid them.

1:12:40 Code Walkthrough: Evaluating Summaries for Hallucinations  
Eugene covers natural language inference (NLI) tasks and fine-tunes models to classify summaries as entailment, neutral, or disagreement.

1:33:03 Evaluating Agents  
Eugene details a step-by-step approach to evaluating agents, including breaking down tasks into classification and quality assessment metrics.

1:35:49 Evals, Rules, Guardrails, and Vibe Checks  
Effective AI evaluation requires a blend of general and task-specific metrics, along with tailored guardrails and validation to ensure accurate outputs.

1:44:24 Auto-Generated Assertions  
Shreya introduces Spade, a tool for generating and refining assertion criteria for AI pipelines by analyzing prompt edits and failures.

1:50:41 Interfaces for Evaluation Assistants  
Shreya discusses the development of more efficient UIs for evaluating and iterating on AI-generated outputs, emphasizing dynamic and human-in-the-loop interfaces to enhance evaluation criteria and processes.

2:04:45 Q&A Session
2:05:58 Streamlining Unit Tests with Prompt History  
2:09:52 Challenges in Unit Testing LLMs for Diverse Tasks  
2:12:20 When to Build Evaluations
2:15:35 Fine-Tuning LLMs as Judges
2:17:00 Building Data Flywheels
2:17:59 Temperature Settings for LLM Calls
2:22:09 Metrics for Evaluating Retrieval Performance in RAG  
2:26:13 Filtering Documents for Accuracy
2:28:14 Unit Tests during CI/CD
2:30:34 Checking for Contamination of Base Models with Evaluation Data

video_title: LLM 평가 및 생산화를 위한 데이터 및 DevOps 도구
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Hamel Husain is a machine learning engineer who loves building machine learning infrastructure and tools 👷🏼‍♂️. He leads or contributes to many popular open-source machine learning projects. He also has extensive experience (20+ years) as a machine learning engineer across various industries, including large tech companies like Airbnb and GitHub.  At GitHub, he led CodeSearchNet, a large language model for semantic search that was a precursor to CoPilot.

Hamel is the founder of Parlance-Labs, a research and consultancy focused on LLMs.  Parlance Labs is working with tech-forward companies like Honeycomb and Rechat to accelerate AI-powered features in their products.  Hamel has a wealth of experience with end-to-end commercial deployments of LLMs, along with hard-won perspectives from working with these technologies in the wild.


Hamel recently joined your host Hugo Bowne-Anderson for a livestreamed recording of Vanishing Gradients to talk about generative AI, large language models, the business value they can generate, and how to get started.

It was so much fun they’re returning just a week later to walk you through an actual industrial use case Hamel is currently working on with Rechat, a real estate CRM, taking you through LLM workflows and tools, including (but not limited to!)
Prompt engineering,
Data quality checks,
LLM evaluation for both human and synthetically generated prompts,
Creating a human-centric UX for interacting with LLMs and their outputs,
Unit tests for LLM output and integrating this into a CI pipeline,
Fine-tuning ChatGPT with your results,
Training classifiers and using RLHF (Reinforcement learning from human feedback).

video_title: Opik 소개: Comet의 오픈소스 LLM 평가
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
www.comet.com | The Comet team is excited to introduce Opik, an end-to-end LLM evaluation platform for developers building LLM-powered applications. With Opik’s LLM observability tooling across your development and production lifecycle, you can build, test, ship, and continuously improve your applications with confidence. 

In this quick intro video, Head of Product Jacques Verré walks through common LLM app development challenges and how to begin solving them with Opik. It all starts with better visibility into your prompt engineering inputs and results: log and annotate traces in development and understand the outcomes generated by your system prompts and test data. Then, perform unit tests on your entire LLM system with Opik’s included LLM evaluation metrics library. Log traces in production to understand your app’s performance and gather test data for your next round of development. 

Opik is available free to self-host, as well as on a generous free cloud tier. Learn more and get started here: https://bit.ly/3N6iop7

video_title: 1분 안에 RAGAS 테스트 세트를 생성하는 방법(코드 포함)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Code: https://github.com/mosh98/RAG_With_Mo...


This comprehensive video provides an in-depth exploration of the Ragas Testset generation. Ragas framework, a pivotal tool designed to assess and enhance your Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines. RAG is about using Large Language Models (LLMs) that utilize external data to expand the context of the model, leading to more informed and accurate outputs.

In this tutorial, we delve into the challenges of evaluating RAG pipelines, and how the Ragas framework (RAG Assessment) revolutionizes this process. You'll learn about the unique features of Ragas, its integration with existing tools, and practical tips on how to effectively quantify and improve the performance of your RAG applications using a generated Test set.

RAGAS github: https://github.com/explodinggradients...
RAGAS Docs: https://docs.ragas.io/en/stable/

Loading Data using Langchain - 1:00
Loading GPT Models - 1:37
Generating TESTSET - 1:50

video_title: 합성 테스트 데이터 생성으로 RAG 챗봇의 정확도를 높이세요!
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this video, I delve into the importance of synthetic test data generation, especially for evaluating RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) augmented pipelines. Manually creating QA samples from documents is time-consuming and often lacks the complexity needed for a thorough evaluation. By leveraging synthetic data, developer time in the data aggregation process can be reduced by 90%.

I also introduce Ragas, a novel approach to generating evaluation data. Unlike standard methods, Ragas uses an evolutionary generation paradigm inspired by works like Evol-Instruct. This approach ensures that your evaluation dataset includes a wide range of question types and difficulty levels, providing a more comprehensive assessment of your pipeline’s performance.

If you find this video helpful, don't forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more content like this!

video_title: [투이컨설팅 122회 Y세미나] 최근 대형 IT 프로젝트, 왜 실패사례가 늘고있을까?
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
📢일정: 2023년 3월 21일 화요일 14:00 - 16:45
📢장소: 전경련타워 파인홀(3층)

최근 대형 IT 프로젝트의 실패사례가 급속히 늘고 있습니다. 프로젝트 현장의 목소리에 귀 기울여보면 단지 우연으로만 치부할 수 없습니다.
기업과 기관들에 요구되는 디지털 전환 속도에 대한 기대는 프로젝트 요구사항 정의를 더욱 어렵게 만들고 있습니다. 현업사용자는 요구사항을 제대로 정의하지 못합니다. 요구사항이 자주 바뀌게 됩니다. 처음에 정한 요구사항이 그대로 가는 경우가 거의 없습니다.
기술이 더욱 복잡해지고 빠르게 발전하고 있습니다. 디지털 전환을 위해 새로운 기술의 도입이 더욱 가속화되고 있지만 이러한 기술을 충분히 습득하지 못하고 있습니다. 또한 대부분의 업무가 이미 전산화되어 있고 내·외부가 복잡하게 연결되어 있습니다. 시스템 이행의 난이도가 급속도로 높아져 있습니다
사람들의 가치관이 변했습니다. 발주자, 수행사, 개발자 모두가 조직을 위해 헌신하기 보다는 자신의 워라밸을 더 중요하게 생각합니다. 위험과 난관을 극복하기 보다는 피하려고 합니다.
기술의 급속한 변화는 개발자들의 숙련도 감소를 유발하고 있으며 이로인해 개발 생산성이 과거보다 낮아졌습니다. 개발자들의 이동도 잦아졌습니다. 프로젝트 도중에도 다른 프로젝트로 이동하기도 합니다.
이러한 문제들이 복합적으로 작용하고 있습니다.

이번 Y세미나에서는 최근 대형 IT프로젝트의 실패 원인을 분석하고 이를 극복하기 위한 방안을 모색하고자 합니다.

자세한 내용은 투이컨설팅 홈페이지를 확인해주세요

video_title: 스크린샷을 사용하여 수동 테스트 케이스를 자동으로 생성하는 방법 | Testcase Studio
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Testcase Studio는 Sanjay Kumar가 개발한 혁신적인 확장 기능으로, 테스트 케이스 자동 생성 프로세스를 간소화합니다. 고급 기능을 통해 사용자 단계를 자동으로 기록하여 수동으로 테스트 케이스를 생성할 필요가 없습니다. 수동 테스터든 자동화 테스터든 테스트 케이스를 작성하게 됩니다.

테스트 케이스 작성은 시간이 많이 소요되는 작업입니다. 하지만 Testcase Studio는 코딩 지식이 전혀 필요하지 않습니다. Testcase Studio는 사용자의 작업을 기록하고, 필요한 단계를 지능적으로 캡처하여 스크린샷과 함께 완벽하게 작동하는 테스트 케이스로 변환합니다.

이러한 단계를 활용하여 버그를 제기하는 동안에도 테스트 케이스를 제작할 수 있습니다. 이를 통해 테스터와 개발자 간의 효율적인 소통이 가능해져 버그 해결 속도가 향상됩니다.

Testcase Studio를 사용하면 귀중한 시간을 절약하고 전반적인 생산성을 향상시킬 수 있습니다.

다운로드 링크 -
https://chrome.google.com/webstore/de...

심층적인 자동화 튜토리얼과 맞춤 노트를 받아보세요.

자바로 플레이라이트: 완벽한 웹 및 API 자동화 프레임워크 시리즈:
   • Automation Testing Using Playwright with J...

무케시 오트와니와 테스트 자동화 소개:
안녕하세요, 저는 인도 방갈로르라는 활기찬 도시에서 열정적으로 활동하는 전문가 무케시 오트와니입니다. 이 채널은 수동 테스터와 QA 전문가 지망생들이 자동화 테스트 세계로 순조롭게 진입할 수 있도록 돕는 데 전념하고 있습니다. 수년간의 실무 경험을 바탕으로 Selenium WebDriver, TestNG, Maven, Appium, Sikuli, AutoIT, Jenkins, Git, GitHub, RPA, Playwright 등 다양한 도구와 기술을 다루는 실용적이고 초보자 친화적인 튜토리얼을 공유합니다. 자동화 여정을 시작하거나 실제 프로젝트에서 얻은 통찰력과 프레임워크 개발을 통해 역량을 향상시키고자 하시는 분이라면, 이 채널이 바로 정답입니다. 구독하고 자동화를 완벽하게 익히고 끊임없이 진화하는 기술 산업에서 앞서 나가기 위해 노력하는 학습자 커뮤니티에 참여하세요.

video_title: Windows용 Jenkins 컨트롤러 및 에이전트 노드 추가 방법 | Jenkins 튜토리얼 | 6부
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
In this video, learn how to add Jenkins controller & Jenkins agent node for Windows. 
Kick Start Testing: https://accounts.lambdatest.com/regis...
Learn more: https://www.lambdatest.com/continuous...

This is Part VI of the Jenkins LambdaTest Tutorial series wherein Moss (@tech_with_moss), a DevOps engineer, explains about configuring Jenkins controller and Jenkins agent nodes to overcome the limitation of a single Jenkins instance. The growing organization needs to scale Jenkins on multiple platforms like Windows, Mac OS, Ubuntu, and Linux. 
Jenkins agents are machines to whom Jenkins controllers can delegate the task of building projects distributed across different platforms that support Java. It allows multi-platform build and testing using the same Jenkins Server.
An agent node might be a windows machine, a Linux machine, or some other platform that supports Java; this allows multi-platform build and testing using the same Jenkins server.  
You will also learn
🔸 How does Jenkins connect to Windows agent?
🔸 Where does Jenkins agent run?
🔸 How does Jenkins agents work?
🔸 How do you deploy Jenkins agent and connect it to Jenkins master?

Ｖɪᴅᴇᴏ Ｃʜᴀᴘᴛᴇʀꜱ

0:40 Problems with single Jenkins Server and Need for Jenkins Controller-Agent setup
1:10 Jenkins Controller/Agent (Master/Slave) Architecture
2:03 How to add a Jenkins Controller Node
5:25 How to add a Jenkins Windows Agent Node for Local system setup
7:38 Configuring the global security to activate the local Windows Jenkins Agent Node
10:00 Testing the Jenkins Controller/Agent setup for Windows
11:48 Conclusion

Hi Friends, I am Anshul Tiwari, and welcome to our youtube channel              I.T. k Funde.

More about this video -  
In this video, we will understand what is a data pipeline with the help of a real-life example. Data pipelines are designed to move data from one point to another. In this video, we will cover below topics -

1 - What is a Data Pipeline?
2 - Why you need a data pipeline?
3 - Basic design of a data pipeline
4 - Types of Data Pipeline - Batch, Streaming, Lambda architecture
5 -  Advanced data pipeline design

We will also learn about various products that can be used in a data pipeline - SAP BODS, Mongo DB, Apache Kafka, Big Query, MDM, Teradata, SAP Business Objects, Tableau.

author: @bigglesharrumpher4139
comment: Great video - it seems while technology has advanced, the concepts of batch loads and real-time data is actually decades old. Back in early 2000's we controlled all ETL and real-time loads with Unix or DOS or SQL scripts that provided return codes for success/failure which triggered alert emails, and we had KPI's for Data quality, backing-out jobs for failed loads, and many other control systems. It just seems there are more 'out-of-the-box' software to handle these now as opposed to custom-built solutions. Great presentation!

Learn the essentials of data engineering in this course for beginners. You'll learn about Databases, Docker, and analytical engineering. You'll explore advanced topics like data pipeline building with Airflow, and engage in batch processing with Spark and streaming data with Kafka. The course culminates in a comprehensive project, putting your skills to the test in creating a full end-to-end pipeline. 

✏️ Justin Chau created this course.

If you're running into an error with "exit code 1" @1:28:55, you need to update the Dockerfile @1:08:08. Goto the Dockerfile and "image: postgres:9.2" for both "source_postgres" and "destination_postgres"


I think this was a good idea but many details went off. I wish he'll be more specific about the version of the software he's using next time.

Airflow와 Python을 활용한 엔드투엔드 데이터 엔지니어링 프로젝트입니다. 이 프로젝트에서는 Twitter API를 사용하여 데이터를 추출하고, Python을 사용하여 데이터를 변환하고, Airflow/EC2에 코드를 배포하고, 최종 결과를 Amazon S3에 저장합니다.

comment:
EDIT:
Elon Musk ruined the API part, you can use some other APIs

Here's one of the subscriber built the same project using other APIs - https://chenmeiqiao.notion.site/How-I-Reach-Out-to-YouTubers-I-Like-As-A-Data-Engineer-c37bdddefde54c3789229ffa5a789432

or you can use a static dataset from Kaggle and then use Airflow to process it


FAQ:
1. Twitter removed free access: It still has free access but with limits of requests you can make - 

2. You need to request for V2 access: You will get an error but just by reading the doc you should be able to access Elevated Access

author: @vijayshreevaibhav
comment:
00:05 A data engineer builds data pipelines to extract, transform, and load data onto a target location.
01:50 Apache Airflow is a viral and widely adopted open-source project for managing data pipelines.
03:33 A workflow in Apache Airflow is called a DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph).
05:10 Apache Airflow has different operators and executors which make task creation and execution easier.
 DAG with Dummy Operator in Airflow
 Apache Airflow allows you to manage DAGs and track their statuses in one place
 Airflow allows you to create complex pipelines and execute Python functions
 Airflow overview and recommended project

author: @saminyead1233
comment: Wow! The amount of value you bring to the viewer in just 12 minutes is just incredible! Like you were saying "the hassle of managing pipelines in python scripts", I made a data project a while back, and I really can understand what you mean. I heard that Airflow makes everything easier, but I kept deferring Airflow learning, partly because "maybe this is good for large data pipelines, but my one consists of just a few small tasks," and also because most YouTube videos of Airflow out there was a couple of hours long. And that's great if you are already committed to learn Airflow, but I was really looking for a video like yours - something that will give me a practical demo of how Airflow actually works, but it will be around 10-15 minutes. And this video was just perfect. Once again, thanks a whole lot! I'll definitely be integrating Airflow into my project now! And my resume too, God willing!

video_title: 코드 따라하기 - 1시간 안에 ELT 파이프라인 구축(dbt, Snowflake, Airflow)
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
How to build an ELT pipeline in 1 hour, using industry standard tools such as dbt, Snowflake and Airflow. This is a live coding tutorial, where I’ll walk you through the thinking process, and show you every step. We’ll cover basic data modeling techniques (fact tables, data marts), snowflake RBAC concepts, and how to orchestrate a dbt project using Airflow. Drop down in the comments section what Data Engineering topics you would like to see in the future!

Timestamps ⏰
0:00 - Intro
1:35 - Setup dbt + Snowflake
7:52 - Configure dbt_project.yml and packages
11:45 - Create source and staging tables
17:41 - Transformed models (fact tables, data marts)
20:25 - Macro functions
24:23 - Generic and singular tests
29:35 - Deploy models using Airflow

Live Coding notes 🎴
https://bittersweet-mall-f00.notion.s...

Who am I? 🙋🏻‍♂️
I'm Jay, I love making videos about travel, self-help and tech. I currently work in New York City as a data engineer, but I grew up in Malaysia and lived in the UK when I was 19. Back then, I had no idea what life was about, moving to so many places, navigating career in Tech. Today, I've learned a lot and wanna share my perspective through filmmaking.

Socials 📱
linkedin:   / jayzern  
insta:   / jayzern

comment:
In this video, you will be building a real-time data streaming pipeline, covering each phase from data ingestion to processing and finally storage. We'll utilize a powerful stack of tools and technologies, including Apache Airflow, Python, Apache Kafka, Apache Zookeeper, Apache Spark, and Cassandra—all neatly containerized using Docker.

MORE FREE COURSES: https://datamasterylab.com

📚 What You'll Learn:
👉 Setting up a data pipeline with Apache Airflow
👉 Streaming data with Kafka and Kafka Connect
👉 Using Zookeeper for distributed synchronization
👉 Data processing with Apache Spark
👉 Data storage solutions with Cassandra and PostgreSQL
👉 Containerizing your data engineering environment with Docker

video_title: What Is DBT and Why Is It So Popular -  Intro To Data Infrastructure Part 3
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
dbt란 무엇일까요?

Fishtown Analytics(현 dbt Labs)에서 개발한 데이터 빌드 도구 또는 dbt는 데이터 분석가, 데이터 엔지니어, 분석 엔지니어가 추출-로드-변환 파이프라인에서 "변환" 단계를 실행할 수 있도록 지원합니다.

SQL로 변환을 작성하고 회사 데이터베이스에 대해 실행하면 됩니다.

"분석 엔지니어링 도구"라고도 불리는 dbt는 오픈 소스이며 많은 기업의 최신 데이터 스택에 필수적인 요소로 자리 잡았습니다. 또한 dbt를 중심으로 탄탄한 지원 커뮤니티가 형성되어 있습니다.

Snowflake, Databricks 또는 Bigquery와 같은 다른 데이터 플랫폼에 로드할 도구를 찾고 계신가요? Estuary를 사용해 보세요. 저는 Estuary와 파트너십을 맺기 전에 여러 고객에게 Estuary를 사용했는데, Estuary 덕분에 전체 프로세스가 훨씬 수월해졌습니다.
https://bit.ly/4eQC3oQ

이 영상이 마음에 드셨다면 다른 인기 영상도 확인해 보세요.

데이터 플랫폼이란 무엇이며 왜 구축해야 할까요?
   • What Is A Data Platform And Why You Should...  

최신 데이터 스택이란 무엇인가 - 데이터 인프라 소개 1부
   • What Is The Modern Data Stack - Intro To D...  

데이터 분야에 대한 최신 소식을 받아보시려면 여기에서 뉴스레터를 구독하세요.

https://seattledataguy.substack.com/

video_title: System Design: TINDER as a microservice architecture
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
다음 면접에서 좋은 결과를 얻고 싶으신가요? 이 시스템 설계 비디오 강좌를 수강해 보세요! 🔥
https://interviewready.io

틴더의 시스템 아키텍처를 설계합니다. 앱 설계는 시스템 요구 사항을 명확히 하는 것부터 시작됩니다. 면접에서 틴더는 여러 가지 요구 사항을 가지고 있습니다.

시스템을 설계할 때는 마이크로서비스 아키텍처를 기반으로 논리적 구성 요소를 도출하고 다른 서비스와의 상호 작용을 정의합니다. 내부 세부 사항은 시스템 설계 개념에 대한 사전 지식을 통해 처리할 수 있다고 가정합니다. 여기에는 부하 분산, 메시지 큐, 데이터베이스 등이 포함됩니다.

틴더 시스템은 프로필 저장, 추천, 매칭 기록, 매칭 상대와의 채팅이라는 네 가지 요구 사항을 가지고 있습니다. 프로필 저장은 이미지 저장을 제외하고는 간단하며, 이미지 저장에서는 BLOB와 파일 저장에 대한 논쟁이 있습니다. 이미지를 저장할 때는 분산 파일 아키텍처가 가장 적합합니다.

다이렉트 메시징이나 매칭 상대와의 채팅은 XMPP 프로토콜을 사용하여 수행할 수 있습니다. XMPP 프로토콜은 웹 소켓을 사용하여 클라이언트와 서버 간에 P2P 통신을 수행합니다. 각 연결은 TCP 기반으로 구축되어 연결이 유지됩니다. 세션 마이크로서비스는 사용자 매핑 연결을 기반으로 수신자에게 메시지를 전송할 수 있습니다.

저희 시스템은 최대한 분리되어 있습니다. 클라이언트에서 수락 및 거부 정보를 유지하려고 노력합니다. 왼쪽이나 오른쪽으로 스와이프할 때 클라이언트는 해당 동작을 기록하고 블룸 필터를 사용하여 동일한 사용자를 다시 표시하지 않을 수 있습니다.

서버에는 매치 마이크로서비스라는 검증 엔진이 있으며, 이 엔진은 매치를 기록하고 두 사용자 간의 채팅을 허용 또는 거부합니다.

추천의 마지막 요건은 사용자 데이터를 도시별로 분할하는 것입니다. 이는 Cassandra나 Amazon Dynamo와 같은 NoSQL 데이터베이스를 사용하여 구현됩니다. 다른 옵션은 수평 분할을 지원하는 관계형 데이터베이스를 사용하는 것입니다. 이 개념을 샤딩이라고 합니다.

의문점, 제안 또는 피드백이 있으시면 아래에 남겨주시기 바랍니다. 이 시스템은 아직 완벽하지는 않지만, 한 시간 분량의 인터뷰를 진행하기에는 충분합니다.

면책 조항: 본 영상에는 Tinder의 내부 구현이 포함되어 있지 않으며, 이를 암시하지도 않습니다. 저희가 디자인한 시스템은 순전히 상상의 산물일 뿐이며, 실제 앱과는 아무런 연관이 없습니다. 틴더 엔지니어들이 이보다 더 나은 시스템을 만들어냈을 거라고 확신합니다!

27:16 추천 엔진
34:40 마무리 지침

author: @anamigator
comment: One thing to remember about databases are they aren't storage wise different from files. What a database provides you is multi user concurrent access without corrupting your data and acid aspects. In theory there's hardly a case where you'd put a big blob in your database. Most often just use paths to big files and keep those paths in the database table. The paths could be on an NFS or whatever distributed file system there is. Your NFS can then deal with geolocation etc. You could create read only mount points across multiple geographical locations for the same file. I'm just leaving this here for anyone to discuss these points further with me. Great video btw!

author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
What are Microservices | Monolithic to Microservices Architecture | Monorepo vs Polyrepo | How Microservices connect with each other
💛   Follow me on IG for behind-the-scenes-content              ►  https://bit.ly/2F3LXYJ
💚  Become a DevOps Engineer - 6-month program:              ►  https://bit.ly/3ou15W0

#microservices  #devops  #techworldwithnana 

►  This video is sponsored by HashiCorp 🙌🏼
►  For more infos about their technologies: https://www.hashicorp.com/

In this video you will learn all you need to know about Microservices in 18 minutes.
First, I will start with what a Monolithic Architecture is, what are some of its challenges and why the industry moved slowly towards the microservices architecture? 
Then we will see what microservices or a microservice architecture is exactly, the best practices, benefits and how the communication between microservices works.
And finally we will also look at the downsides or challenges of a microservices architecture.
We will also see different ways to manage code for microservices application and talk about the difference of monorepo and polyrepo and advantages and disadvantages of both!

video_title: 마이크로서비스 아키텍처란 무엇이고, 어떤 장점이 있나요?
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
마이크로서비스는 시스템 설계 면접에서 중요한 주제입니다. 모놀리식 시스템 대신 마이크로서비스를 사용하는 이유를 아는 것이 중요합니다. 간단히 말하면 확장성입니다. 자세히 설명하면 다음과 같습니다.

장점:
1) 마이크로서비스 아키텍처는 복잡한 시스템을 추론하고 설계하기가 더 쉽습니다.
2) 새로운 구성원이 더 짧은 기간 동안 학습할 수 있고, 시스템을 사용하기 전에 더 적은 맥락을 가질 수 있습니다.
3) 각 서비스에 대한 배포가 유동적이고 지속적입니다.
4) 비즈니스 책임에 따라 서비스 로직을 분리할 수 있습니다.
5) 단일 서비스에 버그가 발생해도 전체 시스템이 중단되지 않으므로 가용성이 더 높습니다. 이를 단일 장애 지점이라고 합니다.
6) 각 서비스를 여러 언어로 작성할 수 있습니다.
7) 개발 팀은 동일한 저장소에서 작업하는 대신 API 시트를 통해 서로 소통할 수 있으며, 이는 충돌 해결을 필요로 합니다.
8) 새로운 서비스를 쉽고 개별적으로 테스트할 수 있습니다. 테스트 구조는 모놀리식에 비해 단위 테스트에 가깝습니다.

마이크로서비스는 경우에 따라 모놀리식보다 불리합니다. 다음과 같은 경우 모놀리식이 유리합니다.
1) 기술/개발자 팀의 규모가 매우 작은 경우
2) 서비스 전체를 이해하기 쉬운 경우
3) 네트워크 호출을 최소화하여 서비스 효율성을 극대화해야 하는 경우
4) 모든 개발자가 모든 서비스에 대한 맥락을 파악해야 하는 경우

추천 시스템 설계 비디오 강좌:
https://interviewready.io

video_title: 마이크로서비스 아키텍처란 무엇이고, 어떤 장점이 있나요?
author: @Live-hh6li
comment:
Monolith - Single/Multiple machine running the computation

Microservice - It's a division of whole works into business units which are turned into specific microservice. 

Adv Monolith:
- Less moving parts
- Good for small teams 
- Less duplication for tests etc
- Faster because everything is in same box(procedure calls)

Disadv Monlith:
- Require more context
- Deployment is complex (everything is touching every other thing)
- Too much responsibility on one server (one can break everything)
- Tight coupling 

Adv Micro:
- Easy to scale
- Less context required
- Parallel development is easy 
- Less hidden parts(more resources can be provided where it is required)

Disadv Micro:
- Tougher to design

Most of the times interviews are high scale and hence micro service is preferred

Thanks for video

video_title: 마이크로서비스 아키텍처란 무엇이고, 어떤 장점이 있나요?
author: @mukundsridhar4250
comment:
This is a very nice channel. Nice work Gaurav. :).


My 2 cents :)
Monolith Advantage / Microservices disadvantage.
1. Transaction management.  
2. One does not have to deal with multiple technology stacks.
3.There is no need to maintain code at the same level for all the services. 
   You don't need to pass on a jar to other services in order to enable resue of code.
4. Latency (as mentioned in the video)


Microservices advantages
1. No single point of failure.
2. You can use the correct technology stack for the required microservice.
3. Decentralized architecture.
4. Decentralized data management.
5. No need to redeploy the whole application. Deployment is faster and easier.
6.Your microservices should be designed across products. SOA is designed around features. This way of thinking is more customer centric.

author: @pavanch3228
comment:
Very good explanation in short video .Just adding few more points of my understanding
Monolith is a single application build for many systems.
In Monolith if any modifications done in the code the whole application should be build and deploy. In case of my microservices only the modified microservices will be deployed.
Monolith uses local calls for interaction where as microservices will use network calls. So here Monolith will give better performance as compared to microservices.
Testing will be easier in microservices because we  test only modified microservice .
In case of Monolith if any changes done need   to perform the functionality testing of whole application to make sure application is working as expected.

video_title: 웹 앱 아키텍처에 대해 알아야 할 모든 것
author: Uploader(Desc)
comment:
Get JetBrains Space for free: https://jb.gg/enjoy_space_for_free
Upgrade to Space Team for free for one month using my code: FORREST

Software architecture for a web application is essentially the blueprint for how a web app is structured. There's monolithic architecture, where you basically piled everything into a single, tightly coupled codebase. But if you want to efficiently scale your app from 100 users to 100,000 users, or want to ensure adding a line of code to a certain component or feature doesn’t break the entire application, then you may want to take a look at the microservice architecture. In the same realm, there's serverless architecture. There's also a higher level of architecture: client-server and peer-to-peer.
When it comes to web app architecture, there are so many different types & many of which aren’t even exclusive from one another. So I’ve broken these down, put them into levels that are actually comparable, and created explanations in a way for you to simply understand the different types of web app architecture, why they’re important, how they play into software development, and given your requirements, goals, and possibilities, which app architecture is best for your app. I hope this helps. Enjoy!

This video is sponsored by JetBrains Space.

video_title: Python 및 Kubernetes를 활용한 마이크로서비스 아키텍처 및 시스템 설계 – 전체 과정
author: @RahMus-d8s
comment:
Very nice tutorial. A few points that I see here that would vastly improve it:

1. Test, test, test! There's coding for 5 hours with no checkpoints in between to test the implementation and functionality.
2. As others have pointed out, MySQL and MongoDB should have been also services in the cluster instead of instances on the local machine. This kind of defeats the purpose of 'microservices'. Either go the whole way or not at all.
3. The file handling (upload and download), should also be separate services. The API gateway responsibility should be to only relay the message from the client to the correct service endpoint. E.g.: user logs in, API gateway calls the auth service. user wants to upload/download, API gateway calls the file_handling service, etc.

But great nevertheless. I hope to see more of these high-level, project-based, system design tutorials!

video_title: Python 및 Kubernetes를 활용한 마이크로서비스 아키텍처 및 시스템 설계 – 전체 과정
author: @AndrewAkaHrun
comment: Very nice tutorial. I wish only you’d start building Python modules with unit tests instead of testing the code manually. Also, I noticed you’re tagging your containers after the build by copying the build reference into the terminal.  One way of simplifying your workflow with containers is to add the tag command right to the build like so: “docker build . -t repo:tag1 -t repo:latest”. Your great educator and a lot of inspiration. Keep posting the videos!

comment:
This Microservices Interview Questions and Answers video will help you to prepare for the Microservices Interviews.

Below are the topics cover in this micro-services interview question and answers tutorial:
1) Basic Microservices Interview Questions
2) Microservices Architecture Interview Questions
3) Migration of monolithic application to microservices
4) Communication between micro-services
5) Continuous Deployment Interview Questions
6) Technologies used in Microservices
7) Microservices best practices
8) Drawbacks of microservices

video_title: 마이크로서비스 면접 질문과 답변 | 아키텍처 설계 및 모범 사례
author: @infomahboobali
comment:
Micro Services Interview Questions

01. so tell me what do you understand by microservices?
Ans: microservice basically decoupling of entire application into small small services. like if I take an example of Amazon or Uber or like you can say any application. so like take example of Amazon okay so in Amazon we'll have like many partners like seller then we will have buyers and at the end we'll have like persons from Amazon who will be managing all the applications or like we'll be seeing the transactions and every other details so we will mention it as an admin so this is an entire application say suppose it is written in Java so what happen is like if I need to change something like in buyer I need to change a small like I want to give an offer of 5% so what I need to do I need to write the code and deploy the entire application so instead of this we can use microservice based architecture where the seller will be a single application buyer will be another application and the admin would be another application so here what happen is like if the admin is down or like if the server is down the entire Amazon website is down so but in this case if admin is down people can use the buyer option or like if the seller is down seller will not be able to add any further items to his store but the buyer can able to check out from his cart and or you can add anything from other sellers or which are already in the stores and if suppose I want to change something in seller and want to deploy, so will just go and deploy this application and the seller what happened is like it may be written in Java it may be written in .net it may be written in node.js so you.

02. so you said that it is a decoupled architecture so coming to that can you explain what are the major differences between service-oriented architecture or monolithic application and a micro service?
Ans:  so what happen is like as I already told that in service-oriented architecture or monolithic application is the entire application so the application monolithic application is the whole block of application service layer or SOA service-oriented architecture is like we define small small module but inside the same application only so we make it modular wise like we take the part of if you take the example of Java we created packages we create interface for particularly for DAO a particularly for seller particularly for customer and particularly for admin and in micro service what we have is like we'll have more granular level of breakdowns like in seller also we can have different types of sellers like from us we can have the part for us only which will be running on any servers on us or we can have clients of any other applications who will be interacting with or auth layer for particularly sellers and auth layer for particularly admin 2 different applications we can have so all these are completely segregated and talked to each other in like over an HTTP and not throw the application himself so if I draw an example like monolithic  SOA and if I take the example of micro service I can say like microservice and there can be N number of microservices okay now I will give you 

03. two scenarios first design a simple micro service architecture application and the second scenario is migrate the existing monolithic application to microservices and what will be your means approach or whatever your thought process to break down those into small small micro services like you took example of Amazon right so you can just show how Amazon can or if you are owner of Amazon that particulars software so how you would have broken it into small small micro services so how I design a micro service is like if it is a new application 
Ans: as you already told since it is a new application so I'll just take the requirements so I will ask like who are the users what are the existing schema how the relationships are mapped like like what are the dependencies like I can have like buyers and sellers so both are actually correlated we can't segregate it out completely so the database, how will manage the databases and all so if I take example of buyer and seller only so buyer will have its own name ID and like items so we have three tables and seller will have like cart details and items brought so these means different tables so this item and this item is related so it is like it can't be like I have brought here like a pan and the buyer doesn't sell a pen or any of the buyers doesn't sell any pen so it it is related so how it interact is like I will call this and suppose he brought already one item or added it so it it will get deleted from here and it will be added here so this is how but these things are completely independent these and these are completely independent so we can keep it out and build two microservices micro-service one and microservices yeah this is how means generally we define micro-services for if I am going for a new application and say it is database and this is database and how we will break a micro surface actually this is a long term process it doesn't work so quickly or so nicely so what we can do is like in monolithic application there we need to change the existing application also side by side and there are micro services so suppose we have buyer-seller and we want to take this out and make it as a micro service so what we can do is like instead of buyer calling this we need to have like a mechanism to call an API so admin will also be there residing and API for admin also and it will point to this micro service so we'll build this micro service we'll take this part this is business logic from here and put it here and once it is done then we'll just point it out instead of calling this we will now call this and instead of calling this we will now call this so this is how we break down so we need to take care of similarly the table structure I mean the schema and we need to means slowly and gradually we need to take these and map so it's like a long term process 
04. while breaking those micro services what so it's like a long term process so while breaking the micro services what are the advantages you have and what are the drawbacks while using all this micro service based architecture
Ans: so the main advantages of micro service is like earlier I told that we will deploy okay so how will define is like a we have buyer then we have seller and we have admin so like Independently we can deploy independently we can make the code change so it's fault tolerant like if it goes down it will be up it will be up then what else one more thing is like we can expand it like we can scale it so like independently we can have entire admin then admin and we can have a load balancer to navigate the traffic and one more thing is like as its mainly practiced by Netflix so like an individual contributor or an individual developer will take like the requirement then he will deploy he will make the code changes then he will deploy it in like cloud or any server independently so he takes a complete responsibility smaller tasks and more thing and one more thing is like it can be written in Java it can be written in node.js so there is no like dependence on any particular technology so anyone can use any technology this is the main criteria so the main problem is like we can have multiple layers of authentication like micro service one is talking to micro service to micro service 3 then it is talking to individually they are talking with each other then micro service 4 the micro service 5 and suppose like so first of all we need to have individual deployment strategy for each one and suppose if something goes failed here so we need to find out we need to find the root cause or why it got failed so we need to debug all the stages here and why it got failed you need to check and on the top of that we need to have multiple layers of authentications, so for micro service 3 it may able to access few of the applications or few of the API so this one will give like auth this one may have authorization type 2 so here we need to implement multiple types of authorization means like for each one individual applications we need to give multiple layers of authentication or authorizations 

05. so you have hierarchical of micro services like micro service one and micro service 2 is talking to micro service 3 suppose which is an auth layer and the micro service 3 is talking to some other micro services like 4 and 5 respectively so if something goes wrong like in micro service layer third or layer 4 something went wrong so how you will know that that micro Service is failing and you need to debug that micro service application logs?
Ans: so to answer your question suppose I have multiple layers of micro services so what we can do is like we can traffic all the logs to Splunk or Kibana or we can say elasticsearch and for each request we can generate a correlation ID so this correlation ID would be passed through each of the headers and it will be logged in the Splunk or like elasticsearch and like suppose if anything goes wrong with this request we can later take out that request and see okay how we can process it from the backend so that's how and if something suppose this server went down so we can have a health check to look for all the servers and suppose this went down the health check will return to the Kibana or email notification like that we can have

author: @eshwareshwar8876
comment:
I really appreciate your efforts, It was so good. Small confusion u took the same example for both SOA and MicroServices. Well said, MicroServices uses smallest possible independent Unit which can be easily modified and deployed. In your example - SOA Buyer module can be further be converted in to Customer-MS1, AddressAndDeliveryAddress-MS2   CommunicationDetails-Normal&ForOrderTracking-MS3 - Here Buyer module can be further divided in to smaller units - Tomorrow if delivery related any extra requirements comes then in that case AddressAndDeliveryAddress-MS2 will get effected and Customer-MS1 will be untouched. I am not sure my example suits in this case or not - I am just adding one more example for better understanding purpose.


Disadvantages of MicroServices not covered- 
                             When it will be difficult to manage 
                             How many maximum number of MS can an product can have, if huge number what are possible challanges, What kind of mechanisms will help to fix dependent issues when you have more and more microServices you have.


Which sectors are not suitable

MicroServices are not suitable for Finance sectors and few other where hudge number of business rules which are interrelated and huge data modifications and data depedndencies.

It is easy pick for CDN, videostream, social media networking related where data is not frequently changing and hence you can bring up more smaller units effortlessly and which becomes easy maintenance and also easy scaling for required ones

상당히 포괄적인? 질문일 수도 있지만 이번에 카프카를 도입하기도 해야하고.. 여러가지 궁금하여 댓글을 달아봅니다.
1. 카프카는 데이터 무결성을 보장하는지? 
2. 데이터 위변조를 막는 방법을 갖고있는지? 갖고 있다면 어떤 방법으로 가능한지?
3. 데이터 저장지 용량 관리는 어떤식으로 해야하는지? 
위 세가지 정도일 것 같습니다. 답변 가능하시다면 정말 감사할 것 같습니다!

author: @IamSystemko
comment: Most of the time we use different approach: each integration test run in a separate transaction and automatically rollbacks at the end of the test. All data tracked by database itself and deleted after test. Of course there are some limitations but it's super simple and effective. Needless to say that library also seems to be interesting to investigate further. Thank you, Nick!

author: @darwinzins
comment:
Nick says something like "it observes it, creates some sql and resets it back to a previous point" which would be fantastic, but the actual description from the github repo is "Respawn resets the database back to a clean, empty state by intelligently deleting data from tables."

Resetting back to a previous point and resetting back to a clean, EMPTY state are two very different things.

So does it actually reset back to a previous point or does it just empty the tables you tell it to empty?
